revision.text:
{{Infobox album | name = Dreamchasers 3 | type = Mixtape | artist = [[Meek Mill]] | cover = Meek Mill Dreamchasers 3.jpg | alt = | released = September 29, 2013 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | length = | label = [[Dream Chasers Records|Dream Chasers]], [[Maybach Music Group]] | producer = {{flatlist| * [[Boi-1da]] * Black Metaphor * [[Cardo (record producer)|Cardo]] * [[Key Wane]] * The Mekanics * R!O * [[Scott Storch]] * Jay Cornell * Super CED * [[Southside (record producer)|Southside]] * [[TM88]] * J. Oliver * [[Lee Major]] * Kamo }} | prev_title = [[Dreams and Nightmares]] | prev_year = 2012 | next_title = [[Dreams Worth More Than Money]] | next_year = 2015 }} '''''Dreamchasers 3''''' is the eighth [[mixtape]] by American [[Rapping|rapper]] [[Meek Mill]]. It was released for free download on September 29, 2013, by [[Maybach Music Group]] and [[Dream Chasers Records]]. The mixtape also released on mixtape hosting websites. The mixtape features [[guest appearance]]s from [[Travis Scott (rapper)|Travis Scott]], [[Sean Combs|Diddy]], [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Rick Ross]], [[Mase]], [[French Montana]], [[Future (rapper)|Future]], [[Yo Gotti]], [[Fabolous]] and [[Jadakiss]], along with his Dream Chasers Records artists [[Lil Snupe]], Omelly, Louie V Gutta and Guordan Banks, among others.
==Background== In November 2012, in an interview with Cosmic Kev producer, [[Jahlil Beats]] stated that he would be producing on ''Dreamchasers 3''.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/jahlil-beats-talks-signing-with-jay-z-and-says-dreamchasers-3-is-coming-news.3520.html |title=Jahlil Beats Talks Signing With Jay-Z & Says "Dreamchasers 3" Is Coming |publisher=Hotnewhiphop.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> On January 5, 2013, Meek Mill revealed a tentative track listing on his [[Instagram]].<ref name="hiphopdxmill">{{cite web|last=Cooper |first=Roman |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.22438/title.meek-mill-dreamchasers-3-cover-art-tracklisting-download-stream |title=Meek Mill "Dreamchasers 3" Cover Art, Tracklisting, Download & Stream |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-09-29 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> On March 8, 2013, Meek Mill announced that the mixtape would be released on May 6, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/03/meek-mill-announces-dreamchasers-3-mixtape-release-date |title=Meek Mill Announces "Dreamchasers 3" Mixtape Release Date |publisher=Complex |date=2013-03-08 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> On August 26, 2013, he announced that the mixtape would be released on September 20, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesource.com/2013/08/26/meek-mill-announces-dreamchasers-3-release-date/ |title=Meek Mill Announces âDreamchasers 3â² Release Date |publisher=TheSource |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> On September 3, 2013, the mixtape was pushed back until September 29, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cooper |first=Roman |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.25317/title.meek-mill-compares-himself-to-lebron-james-discusses-upcoming-projects |title=Meek Mill Compares Himself To LeBron James, Discusses Upcoming Projects |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-09-03 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> The following day, the first song from the mixtape that was released was a track called "I B On That" featuring [[Nicki Minaj]], [[French Montana]] and [[Fabolous]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/09/meek-mill-french-montana-nicki-minaj-fabolous-i-b-on-that |title=Meek Mill f/ French Montana, Nicki Minaj & Fabolous "I B On That" |publisher=Complex |date=2013-09-04 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> On September 11, 2013, he released the final cover artwork for his mixtape.<ref name="hiphopdxmill"/> On September 25, 2013, in an interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', he spoke about a song he was going to make the intro of the mixtape, saying: "Kendrick's verse. Kendrick's verse, man. [Laughs] I don't know if I'ma keep it, though. Some of the guys I'm throwing shots at, I'm actually cool with these guys and I don't really be throwing shots at guys I'm cool with ... that really was influenced by the Kendrick shit, so we'll determine by tonight if I'ma finish that or not. My focus is on the intro, on making another fire-ass intro that I can go crazy to in the club."<ref>{{cite web|author=Jeff Rosenthal |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-meek-mill-on-dreamchasers-3-and-his-expensive-watch-20130926 |title=Meek Mill Previews 'Dreamchasers 3' Mixtape in New York City | Music News |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2013-09-26 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref>
==Promotion== On October 1, 2013, the music video was released for "I B On That" featuring Nicki Minaj, French Montana and Fabolous.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/10/01/video-meek-mill-f-nicki-minaj-fabolous-french-montana-i-b-on-dat/ |title=Video: Meek Mill f/ Nicki Minaj, Fabolous, & French Montana â âI B on Datâ |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> On December 11, 2013, the music video was released for "I'm Leanin" featuring [[Travis Scott (rapper)|Travis Scott]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/12/11/video-meek-mill-f-travis-scott-im-leanin/ |title=Video: Meek Mill f/ Travi$ Scott â âIâm Leanin |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date=2013-09-29 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref> On January 31, 2014, the music video was released for "Heaven or Hell" featuring [[Jadakiss]] and Guordan Banks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2014/01/30/video-meek-mill-f-jadakiss-guordan-banks-heaven-or-hell/ |title=Video: Meek Mill f/ Jadakiss & Guordan Banks â âHeaven or Hellâ |publisher=Rap-Up.com |date=2014-01-30 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref>
==Critical response== {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]] | rev1Score ={{Rating|4|5}}<ref name="autogeneratedmill">{{cite web|last=Rohn |first=Jake |url=http://www.bet.com/news/music/2013/10/01/mixtape-review-meek-mill-dreamchasers-3.html |title=Mixtape Review: Meek Mill, Dreamchasers 3 | News |publisher=BET |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> | rev2 = [[HipHopDX]] | rev2Score = (positive)<ref name="hhdx">{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Bruce |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/album-reviews/id.2156/title.meek-mill-dreamchasers-3-mixtape-review- |title=Meek Mill - Dreamchasers 3 (Mixtape Review) |publisher=HipHop DX |date=2013-10-03 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> | rev3 = [[Stereogum]] | rev3Score = (positive)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1505181/mixtape-of-the-week-meek-mill-dreamchasers-3/franchises/mixtape-of-the-week/ |title=Mixtape Of The Week: Meek Mill Dreamchasers 3 |publisher=Stereogum |date=2013-10-16 |accessdate=2013-11-06}}</ref> | rev4 = ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]'' | rev4Score = {{Rating|3|5}} (L)<ref name="xxlmagmill">{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/reviews/2013/10/meek-mill-keeps-it-consistent-with-his-dreamchasers-3-mixtape/ |title=Meek Mill Keeps It Consistent With His 'Dreamchasers 3' Mixtape - XXL |publisher=Xxlmag.com |date=2013-10-03 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> | rev5 = ''[[Wellington Daily News]]'' | rev5Score = (positive)<ref>{{cite web|author=DreamChasers 3 review |url=http://www.wellingtondailynews.com/article/20130930/BLOGS/309309941 |title=DreamChasers 3 review - Blogs - Wellington Daily News - Wellington, KS |publisher=Wellington Daily News |date= |accessdate=2013-11-06}}</ref> }} ''Dreamchasers 3'' was met with generally positive reviews from [[music criticism|music critic]]s. Jake Rohn of [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]] gave the mixtape four out of five stars, saying "''Dreamchasers 3'', like most mixtapes, does have some filler like "My Life" and the monotonous "We Ain't the Same" (which ironically bares too much similarity to what every other rapper is saying on records these days). It's not perfect, but it's pretty close.With Meek's current momentum, a slew of fellow dreamchasers in his corner and one of the strongest teams in the game behind him, he is establishing himself again as a true star on this tape and a deadly opponent on the mic."<ref name="autogeneratedmill"/> Bruce Smith of [[HipHopDX]] gave the album a positive review, saying "Fans of Meek Millâs ''[[Dreamchasers]]'' or ''[[Dreamchasers 2]]'', are bound to find much to like about ''Dreamchasers 3''. However, when Meekâs competition is talking about raising the bar lyrically, and he continues to rap about repo-ing women, and comparing diamond flooded watches to the disaster that was Hurricane Katrina, it wonât be surprising if his overall standing within the game takes another hit. This edition of "''Dreamchasers''" is closed out with what sounds to be an intro to Meekâs next effort, and hopefully that project shows the growth many think Meek Mill is capable of."<ref name="hhdx"/> Emmanuel C.M. of ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]'' gave the mixtape an L, saying "Even though the tape isnât game changing, it does show that Meek is very capable of making propulsive rap music that can also serve as hits. No longer is he only capable of making street anthems; he can actually churn out a vast array of records that will actually get spins. The growth is there. Heâs using his strength, raw emotion and skill as a storyteller, and mastering his craft as an artist. However, this is far from the main course, just a table of different selections to temper the appetite."<ref name="xxlmagmill"/>
On December 24, 2013, ''XXL'' ranked it at number 20 of their list of best mixtapes of the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/12/the-25-best-mixtapes-of-2013/3/ |title=The 25 Best Mixtapes Of 2013 - Page 3 of 6 - XXL |publisher=Xxlmag.com |date=2013-12-24 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref>
==Track listing== {{Tracklist | extra_column = Producer(s) | title1 = Im Leanin (Intro) | note1 = featuring [[Travis Scott (rapper)|Travis Scott]], [[Birdman (rapper)|Birdman]] & [[Sean Combs|Diddy]] | extra1 = Cardo | length1 = 3:44

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=April 2009}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Fab Morvan | image = Academy Awards afterparty CUN Fab Morvan.jpg | caption = Fab Morvan at the 79th Annual Academy Awards, Children Uniting Nations/ Billboard afterparty, 2007. | image_size = 250px | background = solo_singer | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1966|05|14|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], France | death_date = | origin = [[Guadeloupe]], France | genre = [[Dance-pop]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[new jack swing]] | years_active = 1988âpresent | label = [[Arista Records]], [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]], Elixir Records, [[Hansa Records]] and Joss Entertainment Group | associated_acts = [[Milli Vanilli]], [[Rob & Fab]], [[Boney M.]] | website = [http://www.fabmorvan.com/] }} '''Fabrice Morvan''' (born 14 May 1966) is a French singer-songwriter, dancer and model. He was half of the pop duo [[Milli Vanilli]], with [[Rob Pilatus]], selling multi-platinum albums around the world. However, he was later involved in one of the largest [[scandal]]s in pop music history when it was revealed that neither he nor Pilatus had actually sung on any of Milli Vanilli's recordings. After the scandal, the group reformed as [[Rob & Fab]] in the 1990s with limited success. Morvan had a solo comeback in the 2000s releasing his first solo album, ''[[Love Revolution (Fabrice Morvan album)|Love Revolution]]''.
==Biography==
===Early years=== Morvan was born in 1966 in Paris, France, to parents from [[Guadeloupe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/milli-vanilli-p4917/biography|title=Milli Vanilli â Biography}}</ref> At 18, he moved to Germany, where he was a dancer and model, and was influenced by [[funk]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[Pop music|pop]]. He met Rob Pilatus in a nightclub in [[Munich]]. They decided to form a rock/soul group.
=== Fame === Morvan and Pilatus were noticed by music producer [[Frank Farian]], who signed them as part of a musical act. Shortly after a trip to [[Turkey]], where they reputedly got the band's name from a local advertising [[slogan]], Milli Vanilli was born. Morvan and Pilatus served as the public faces for singers [[Charles Shaw (singer)|Charles Shaw]], John Davis, and [[Brad Howell (singer)|Brad Howell]], who Farian thought were talented musicians but lacked a marketable image.
The first Milli Vanilli album was ''[[Girl You Know It's True]]''. Despite critical derision, Milli Vanilli's fame continued to grow worldwide. The album had four hit singles: [[Girl You Know It's True (song)|the title track]], and the group's three #1 hits, "[[Girl I'm Gonna Miss You]]", "[[Baby Don't Forget My Number]]", and "[[Blame It on the Rain]]". Milli Vanilli won the [[Grammy Award]] for Best New Artist on 22 February 1990 for ''Girl You Know It's True''.
Morvan and Pilatus were a frequent target of rumours and allegations of on-stage [[Lip sync|lip-synching]] and not having sung on the album. Shaw told a reporter the truth about Milli Vanilli, but recanted after Farian paid him $150,000 to do so{{Citation needed|date=July 2016}} .
When Morvan and Pilatus pressured Farian to let them sing on the next album, Farian admitted to reporters on 15 November 1990 that Morvan and Pilatus had not actually sung on any of the records. As a result, Milli Vanilli's Grammy was withdrawn four days later and [[Arista Records]] dropped the act from its roster and deleted their album and its masters from their catalog, thus making ''Girl You Know It's True'' one of the largest-selling albums to ever be taken out of print. A court allowed any American who bought the album to get a refund.
Farian would later attempt a failed comeback for the group without Morvan and Pilatus.
===Aftermath=== Months later, Morvan and Pilatus parodied the scandal in a commercial for Carefree [[Chewing gum|sugarless gum]]. They began to lip sync to an opera recording. An announcer asked as they were lip synching, "How long does the taste of Carefree sugarless gum last?" The record then began to skip and the announcer answers, "Until these guys sing for themselves."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CEEDE1331F937A25755C0A967958260|title=Milli Vanilli Appears Again|last=Elliott|first=Stuart|date=14 June 1991|work=The New York Times |accessdate=2011-10-27}}</ref>
They then moved to [[Los Angeles]], where they released an eponymous album under the name ''[[Rob & Fab]]''. Despite positive reviews from critics, the album failed due to financial constraints, poor promotion, and the scandal surrounding Milli Vanilli's lip-synching allegations. The album itself only sold around 2,000 copies.
Pilatus later served three months jail for assault, vandalism, and attempted robbery. He spent six months on drug rehabilitation before returning to Germany. He died of an alcohol and prescription drug overdose at a hotel in [[Frankfurt]] on 2 April 1998.
===Solo comeback=== Morvan spent several years as a [[session musician]] and [[public speaker]]. In 1998, he was hired as a [[radio programming|radio]] [[Disc jockey#Radio DJs|DJ]] at famed L.A. radio station [[KIIS-FM]]. During this time, he also performed at the station's sold-out 1999 [[Wango Tango]] festival concert before 50,000 people at [[Dodger Stadium]].
In 1997, Morvan was interviewed for the premiere episode of [[VH1|VH-1]]'s ''[[Behind the Music]]''. He was also featured in a 2000 [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] documentary on Milli Vanilli. Morvan then spent 2001 on tour, before performing in 2002 as the inaugural performer at the brand-new Velvet Lounge at the [[Hard Rock CafÃ©]] Hotel in [[Orlando, Florida]].
In 2003, Morvan released his first solo album, ''[[Love Revolution (Fabrice Morvan album)|Love Revolution]]'', producing, recording, writing and singing all the tracks. On 14 April 2011, Morvan released a new single, "Anytime", to digital outlets.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
On 25 May 2012, Morvan released a single, "See the Light" with a new band, Fabulous Addiction.
In March 2014, it was mentioned that Morvan was working on his next single in Los Angeles with Grammy-winning viral producer [[Clarence Jey]] and Grammy-winning singer Delious Kennedy from U.S. R&B group [[All-4-One]].
Morvan also DJs for private [[Heineken International|Heineken]] functions at the [[Heineken Experience]] center in Amsterdam. As a solo musician, Morvan has worked with several DJ/producers including [[Don Diablo]], Guy J, Dance Spirit, Desert Minds, DJ Prinz, Patrick BP Bruyndonx, MuziJunki, Sean McCaff, Limoncello, Guan Elmzoom, and has collaborated on well-received dance releases with several. Some of his other pursuits include writing, painting and fashion design.
=== Film and ''Best of the Best'' album === On 14 February 2007, it was announced that [[Universal Pictures]] was developing a film based on the true story of Milli Vanilli's rise and fall in the music industry. [[Jeff Nathanson]], screenwriter from ''[[Catch Me If You Can]]'', was to write and direct the film. Morvan was supposed to serve as a consultant, providing his and Pilatus' point of view.<ref>[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117959531.html?categoryid=16&cs=18query=Milli+Vanilli+film Variety.com : Universal sets up Milli Vanilli film]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, by Michael Fleming, 14 February 2007</ref><ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2007/02/20/girl-you-know-its-true-milli-vanill-biopic-will-reveal-the-truth/ RollingStone.com : Girl, You Know It's True: Milli Vanilli Biopic will reveal the truth (!)], by Nicole Frehsee, 20 February 2007</ref> However, the project was never completed. In 2011 German director [[Florian Gallenberger]] declared that he was reviving the project and would be rewriting the script.<ref>[http://www.ifc.com/fix/2011/02/the-milli-vanilli-film âMilli Vanilliâ Movie Gets Rewrite And New Director, FIX, 16 February 2011]</ref>
On 26 March 2007, the Milli Vanilli ''[[Best of the Best (Milli Vanilli album)|Best of the Best]]'' album was released.
Morvan now resides in [[Amsterdam]] and [[Los Angeles]] as of 2010.<ref>http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20446957,00.html</ref>
==Discography== ===Solo albums=== *''[[Love Revolution (Fabrice Morvan album)|Love Revolution]]'' (2003)
===with Milli Vanilli=== *''[[All or Nothing (Milli Vanilli album)|All or Nothing]]'' (1988) *''[[Girl You Know It's True]]'' (1989)
===with Rob & Fab=== *''[[Rob & Fab]]'' (1993)
===with Fabulous Addiction=== *"See the Light" (2012)
===with NightAir=== *"[[One of These Nights (song)|One of These Nights]]" (2014)<ref>[http://emmagazine.be/article/274/sony-music-presents-nightair-news/ EM Magazine: Sony Music Presents NightAir]</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}

'''Margaretha "Greta" Keller''' (February 8, 1903 – November 11, 1977) was a cabaret singer and actress.
==Biography== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2017}}
===Early years=== Born '''Margaretha Keller''' in [[Vienna, Austria]], she studied dance from the age of eight, followed by acting. Her dÃ©but was in ''Pavillon,'' in Vienna. She also appeared on stage with [[Marlene Dietrich]] in ''Broadway,'' in which she sang and danced.
A recording contract with Ultraphon in 1929 took her from Vienna to [[Prague]] and [[Berlin]], where she enjoyed great success with [[Peter Igelhoff]] and Peter Kreuder. For over 45 years her voice was familiar worldwide, in radio shows, films, revues, concerts and musicals, but above all in recordings. First called ''The Great Lady Of Chanson'' in her native Vienna, the nickname followed her to [[London]] and [[United States|America]].
===Personal life=== Greta Keller's first marriage to the singer Joe Sargent (1928) did not last. He turned out to be an alcoholic. Her second marriage started and ended in [[Hollywood, California|Hollywood]] where she met and married [[David Bacon (actor)|Gaspar Griswold Bacon, Jr.]] son of [[Gaspar G. Bacon]] from a prominent "[[Boston Brahmin]]" family. The elder Bacon was a member of the board of [[Harvard University]], and had been a close associate of [[J.P. Morgan]], and later served as Secretary of State under [[Theodore Roosevelt]] and ambassador to France under [[William Howard Taft]].
Her husband, known in film and theater as [[David Bacon (actor)|David Bacon]], was murdered in 1943, two weeks after finishing a major role in the [[Republic Pictures|Republic]] serial ''[[The Masked Marvel]]''. Speculation involved affairs with [[Howard Hughes]] and another actor, but the murder investigations ceased without a result and the files later disappeared. Due to that shock and a counter-indicated dose of morphein administered by Bacon's brother, a physician, Greta's child with Bacon was stillborn. It took some time for her to recover from these events, but she restarted her career in [[Switzerland]], then on to Vienna, [[Berlin]] and back to [[New York City]].
Greta Keller's last long-time relationship: The last years of her life, from 1973 until her death in November 1977 Greta lived, worked, and traveled with her last partner, Wolfgang Nebmaier, who now lives in Southern Oregon, tends to his wife and their goats and other animals and writes stage and screen plays. (See also Chanteusemovie.com).
===Career=== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2017}} Her [[lieder]] voice carried the charm of the [[Paris]]ian women but never lost the heart of the girl from [[Vienna]]. Greta's singing in what some call "a style reminiscent of Marlene Dietrich" comes from the fact she was the model for how Marlene Dietrich developed her own voice. Greta Keller made recordings throughout the world and from the 1920s into the 1970s. She spent many years in the [[United States]], notably in hotel club rooms at the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel|Waldorf]] and (later) the [[Stanhope Hotel|Stanhope]] in New York, where her show always included "''[[My Way (song)|My Way]]''", with lyrics composed by [[Paul Anka]], and a number of [[NoÃ«l Coward]] numbers. A "singer's singer," Keller often drew other performers to the room, including the [[Nordstrom Sisters]], [[Beverly Sills]] and [[Hildegarde]].
Other regulars would book the same tables most nights that she was performing, including photographer [[Edgar de Evia]]. Favorites of the Stanhope crowd were the songs of [[Cole Porter]] and NoÃ«l Coward, for their sexual innuendo and double entendres. These included "[[Miss Otis Regrets]]" and "I'm the Other Woman in His Life" by her close friend Elisse Boyd. She regularly returned to Vienna. The poet and singer [[Rod McKuen]] was introduced by her to an audience in Vienna. McKuen, in turn, hosted a concert presenting her at [[Lincoln Center]] in the 1970s, and wrote the English lyric "[[If You Go Away]]" to [[Jacques Brel]]'s "Ne Me Quitte Pas," which she always sang.
Her repertoire included songs from the 1930s through the [[World War II|war years]] as well as popular songs of the day. A few years before her death, her voice was heard in the [[Academy Award]]-winning movie, ''[[Cabaret (1972 film)|Cabaret]]'' (1972), for which she sang the song, ''"Heirat" (Married)''.
[[File:Wiener Zentralfriedhof - Gruppe 40 - Greta Keller.jpg|thumb|Grave of Greta Keller]] Keller was buried on the [[Wiener Zentralfriedhof]].
===Filmography=== * ''[[The Man in Search of His Murderer]]'' (1931) * Lied vom Leben, Das (1931) .... Singer... a.k.a. Song of Life (USA: informal literal English title) * ''[[Melody of Love (film)|Melody of Love]]'' (1932) .... Singer... a.k.a. Right to Happiness (USA) * Abenteurer von Paris, Der (1936) .... Cabaret Singer... a.k.a. The Paris Adventure (USA) * Reunion in France (1942) (uncredited) .... Baroness von Steinkamp... a.k.a. Mademoiselle France (UK)... a.k.a. Reunion * Herz spielt falsch, Ein (1953) .... Chansonniere/Cabaret Singer ... a.k.a. A Heart's Foul Play (International: English title) * Blaue Stunde (1967) .... Singer * Cabaret (1972) her voice was heard on a record as the singer of: "Heirat"
==Filmography as: Actor, Herself, Notable TV Guest Appearances==
===Herself – filmography=== * Underground and Emigrants (1976)
===Notable TV Guest Appearances=== * "Five Fingers" playing "Micheline" in episode: "Station Break" (episode # 1.1) 3 October 1959 * "'Drehscheibe, Die'" playing "Singer" 6 November 1968 * "V.I.P.-Schaukel" playing "Herself" (episode # 4.3) 15 December 1974
== External links == * {{IMDb name|id=0445643|name=Greta Keller}} * [http://www.folkways.si.edu/https://folkways.si.edu/search?query=Greta+Keller/ Keller Discography on Folkways]

Valentino{{cite web|url=https://letterboxd.com/film/hardcore-2001/|title=Hardcore 2001 film|publisher=letterboxd.com|accessdate=2017-06-25}} |music = [[Richard Attree]] |cinematography = [[Richard Ranken]] |editing = Chris King |released = {{start date|2001|04|07|df=y}} |runtime = |country = [[United Kingdom]] |language = [[English language|English]] }} '''''Hardcore''''' is a [[2001 in film|2001]] british documentary film directed by [[Stephen Walker (filmmaker)|Stephen Walker]].This film has bean music composed by [[Richard Attree]].The film starring Robert Black, [[David Christopher]], [[Mark Handel]], [[Max Hardcore]], [[Brandon Iron]] and [[Mr. Marcus]] in the lead roles.{{cite web|url=https://www.thefword.org.uk/2001/04/hardcore/|title=Hardcore|publisher=thefword.org.uk|accessdate=2017-06-25}} ==Cast== * Robert Black * [[David Christopher]] * [[Mark Handel]] * [[Max Hardcore]] * [[Brandon Iron]] * [[Layla Jade]] * Joel Lawrence{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/NoFap/comments/289mcs/hardcore_documentary_2001//|title=Hardcore Documentary (2001)|publisher=reddit.com|accessdate=2017-06-25}} * [[Mr. Marcus]] * [[Lee-anne McQueen]] * [[Dick Nasty]] * [[Kyle Phillips]] * [[Caroline Pierce]] * [[Michael Stefano]] * [[Steve Taylor]] * Valentino{{cite web|url=http://www.moviepilot.de/movies/hardcore--3|title=Hardcore|publisher=moviepilot.de|accessdate=2017-06-25}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0322500}} [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2001 films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:Films shot in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:British documentary films]] {{UK-documentary-film-stub}}

{{Infobox song | name = Judy's Turn to Cry | cover = Judy's Turn to Cry.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Lesley Gore]] | album = [[I'll Cry If I Want to]] | B-side = Just Let Me Cry | released = June 1963 | format = | recorded = May 14, 1963 | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[rock music|rock]] | length = 2:12 | label = [[Mercury Records]] | writer = [[Beverly Ross]], Edna Lewis | producer = [[Quincy Jones]] | prev_title = [[It's My Party (Lesley Gore song)|It's My Party]] | prev_year = 1963 | next_title = [[She's a Fool]] | next_year = 1963 }} '''"Judy's Turn to Cry"''' is a song written by [[Beverly Ross]] (who also co-wrote [[Roy Orbison]]'s "[[Candy Man (Roy Orbison song)|Candy Man]]"){{cite book|title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Fifties Music|author=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Larkin, C.]]|page=315|year=1998|publisher=Virgin|isbn=}} and Edna Lewis that was originally released by [[Lesley Gore]] in 1963. The song was produced by [[Quincy Jones]], who also produced Gore's prior hit "[[It's My Party (Lesley Gore song)|It's My Party]]".{{cite web|title=Judy's Turn to Cry|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/judys-turn-to-cry-t2601612|author=Viglione, J.|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=July 19, 2011}} It was released on Gore's first album ''[[I'll Cry If I Want To]]'' and also as a single which reached #5 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart and #10 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|Billboard R&B singles chart]].{{cite web|title=Lesley Gore Charts and Awards|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lesley-gore-p4387/charts-awards/billboard-singles|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=July 19, 2011}}{{cite book|title=The classic rock and roll reader: rock music from its beginnings to the mid-1970s|author1=Studwell, W.E. |author2=Lonergan, D.|page=252|year=1999|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-7890-0151-1}} The single earned a [[gold record]].{{cite book|title=The Guinness encyclopedia of popular music, Volume 3|author=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Larkin, C.]]|page=1705|year=1995|edition=2|publisher=University of California|isbn=978-1-56159-176-3}} When "It's My Party" entered the Billboard Hot 100 on May 11, 1963, Gore's label, [[Mercury Records]] rushed to record a sequel.{{cite book|title=Goldmine roots of rock digest|page=183|author=''[[Goldmine Magazine]]''|publisher=Krause Publications|year=1999|isbn=978-0-87341-775-4}} The sequel, "Judy's Turn to Cry," was recorded on May 14, 1963. In "It's My Party," the singer was in tears because her boyfriend Johnny left with her best friend Judy. In "Judy's Turn to Cry," the singer kisses another boy at another party in order to make Johnny jealous and Johnny hits the other boy and returns to her.{{cite book|title=Rock 'n' roll: Gold rush : a singles un-encyclopedia|author=Dean, M.|page=189|year=2003|publisher=Algora Publishing|isbn=978-0-87586-207-1}}{{cite web|title=It's My Party|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/its-my-party-t2601611|author=Ankeny, J.|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=July 20, 2011}}{{cite book|title=Liner notes-20th Century Masters â The Millennium Collection: The Best of Lesley Gore|author=Sachs, T.|date=July 200|publisher=Mercury Records}} In the [[refrain|chorus]], which also opens the song, the triumphant singer gloats that "Well now it's Judy's turn to cry, Judy's turn to cry, Judy's turn to cry; 'cause Johnny's come back to me."{{cite book|title=Angel Courage: 365 Meditations and Insights to Get Us Through Hard Times|author1=Taylor, T.L. |author2=Crain, M.B.|page=2|year=1999|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-251583-4}} Until then the singer's "tears just fell like rain drops" because "Judy's smile was so mean." With its emphasis on cryingâin this case Judy rather than the singerâthe song fit in with the theme of the album ''I'll Cry If I Want To'', in which most of the songs involved someone crying.{{cite web|title=I'll Cry If I Want to|author=Unterberger, R.|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/ill-cry-if-i-want-to-r8439/review|publisher=[[allmusic]]|accessdate=July 19, 2011}} The song's instrumentation includes drums and horns. [[Allmusic]] critic Joe Viglione describes "Judy's Turn to Cry" as having "a monstrous hook as valuable as 'It's My Party' with violence that may have been inspired by [[The Crystals]] pushing the envelope with their withdrawn classic '[[He Hit Me (It Felt Like a Kiss)]]'". Viglione also notes that because both "It's My Party" and "Judy's Turn to Cry" are short, both at just under 2:20, and both songs are different from each other, and each starts off with its own identifiable hook, and the choruses are different but the verses tell one continuous story, the two songs could be played on the radio back to back, allowing Gore to sing the entire "soap opera." This song is in the key of D Major, while "It's my Party" is in the key of A Major.{{cite book|title=Musicological identities: essays in honor of Susan McClary|author=McClary, S., Knapp, R., Baur, S. & Warwick, J.C.|page=71|year=2008|publisher=Ashgate|isbn=978-0-7546-6302-7}} Connie Landers sang the two songs back to back on the 2008 album ''Girls Girls Girls: 1960's Rock N Roll''.{{cite web|title=Girls Girls Girls: 1960's Rock N Roll|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/girls-girls-girls-1960s-rock-n-roll-r1396619|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=July 19, 2011}} Author Maury Dean notes that Gore's "crisp [[soprano]] uses very sophisticated [[jazz]] progressions." Music journalist [[Lillian Roxon]] commented that "you could savor every bitchy second of Lesley's triumph with her sequel 'Judy's Turn to Cry.'"{{cite book|title=Rock Encyclopedia|author=[[Lillian Roxon|Roxon, L.]]|page=207|year=1974|publisher=University of Michigan|isbn=}}{{cite book|title=Mother of Rock: The Lillion Roxon Story|author=Milliken, R.|page=274|year=2010|edition=2|publisher=Black, Inc.|isbn=978-1-4587-8017-1}} Subsequent to initial release as a single and on ''I'll Cry If I Want To'', "Judy's Turn to Cry" has been released on numerous Lesley Gore compilation albums. These include ''The Golden Hits of Lesley Gore'' in 1965, ''It's My Party: The Mercury Anthology'' in 1996, ''Sunshine, Lollipops, and Rainbows: The Best of Lesley Gore'' in 1998, ''20th Century Masters â The Millennium Collection'' in 2000 and ''The Ultimate Collection 1963â1968: Start the Party Again'' in 2005.{{cite web|title=Judy's Turn to Cry|url=http://www.allmusic.com/search/track/Judy%27s+Turn+to+Cry/order:default-asc|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=July 19, 2011}} It has also been included on a number of multi-artist compilations of 1960s songs. ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !Chart (1963) !Peak
position |- |US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] |align="center"|5 |- |US [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|Hot R&B Sides]] |align="center"|10 |- |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{MetroLyrics song|lesley-gore|judys-turn-to-cry}} {{Lesley Gore}} [[Category:Lesley Gore songs]] [[Category:1963 songs]] [[Category:1963 singles]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Quincy Jones]] [[Category:Mercury Records singles]] [[Category:Sequel songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Beverly Ross]]

[[File:Wooden Mancala board.jpg|thumb|right|A wooden [[mancala]] board.]] '''Layli Goobalay''' (or '''Layli Goobaly''') is a board game played in parts of [[Somalia]]. It is a variant of the classical [[count and capture]] game ''mancala'' (from the [[Arabic language|Arabic]] word ''naqala'', meaning literally "to move"), which is one of the oldest two-player strategy board games played throughout the world. ''Layli Goobalay'' means "to exercise with circles" in the [[Somali language]].<ref name="Rsolg">{{cite web|title=Layli Goobalay|url=http://www.redsea-online.com/modules.php?name=games&func=display&gameid=1|publisher=Red Sea Online|accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref>
==Rules== Layli Goobalay is played on a 2x6 mancala board (i.e., 2 rows of 6 pits each), with 48 seeds. At game setup, 4 seeds are placed in each pit. Similar equipment and game setup are used for in other mancalas.
At his or her turn, the player takes all the seeds from a pit and [[Mancala#General gameplay|sows]] them counterclockwise. If the last seed of a sowing falls in a non-empty pit that is not a ''Uur'' (see below), [[Mancala#General gameplay|relay-sowing]] applies. Thus, the player's turn ends when the last seed in a sowing is dropped in an empty pit or in a ''Uur'' pit. Depending on the pit where this last seed was dropped, the following situations may occur:
* if the pit is a ''Uur'', nothing happens; * if the pit is in the opponent's row, nothing happens; * if the pit is the player's row, and the adjacent pit in the opponent's row is empty, nothing happens; * if the pit is the player's row, and the adjacent pit in the opponent's row is non empty, the seeds in the opponent's pit are captured. This in turn may lead to two consequences: ** if the opponent's pit contains 3 seeds, one of those seeds is captured and placed in the same pit as the capturing seed. The two pits involved in the capture thus will have 2 seeds each. Those are termed ''Uur'' (meaning "pregnant") and they now belong to the player who captured; ** if the opponent's pit contains any other number of seeds, all those seeds as well as the capturing seed are removed from the game.
A player can never begin a sowing from ''Uur'' pits, and relay-sowing does not apply to ''Uur'' pits. Consequently, the content of ''Uur'' pits tends to grow over time.
The game ends when one of the player can no longer move. Both players then capture the seeds from their own ''Uur''s (remember that a player can own a ''Uur'' in the opponent's row) and from the other pits in their own rows. The player who captured most seeds wins the game.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * {{it icon}} [[Jama Musse Jama]], ''Layli Goobalay: Variante somala del "gioco nazionale africano"''. Ponte Invisibile Edizioni, [[Pisa]], (2002).
==External links== * {{it icon}} [http://www.pergioco.net/Giochi/Abstrakta/Oware/Oware.htm Rules] (by Jama Musse Jama) * [http://www.redsea-online.com/modules.php?name=games&func=display&gameid=1 Rules]
[[Category:Traditional mancala games]] [[Category:Somali games]]

{{italic title|all=yes|string=Prisoner}} The following is a list of home video releases from the Australian television series ''[[Prisoner (TV series)|Prisoner]]'' (internationally re-titled ''Prisoner: Cell Block H'' in the United States and the United Kingdom, and ''Caged Women'' in Canada). The entire series, consisting of 8 seasons and 692 episodes is available in both Australia and the UK. Initially released in "Best Of" compilation format on DVD in Australia with three sets, in the United States with the first two sets, and in the United Kingdom with only the first set. In Australia, [[Shock Records]] commenced releasing what was to be the beginning of the entire series in 2006 in volume format on DVD; the complete series over 40 volumes. Prior to the release of Volume 13, "The Complete Collection" was made available with the remaining individual volumes released subsequently. A second version of "The Complete Collection" was released in 2011. All of the original sets are now out-of-print. As of late 2016, ViaVision are releasing ''Prisoner'' on DVD in their original complete season formats. In the United Kingdom, the series began releasing on VHS with the first 12 episodes over six videos and a video containing episodes 326 & 327. ''Prisoner Cell Block H'' DVDs have been released in stages by FremantleMedia Home Entertainment between 2008 - 2013. The content on the discs is identical to the Australian release, but with different cover/sleeve artwork. The UK releases started out as boxed sets of eight discs (32 episodes) with two discs in four cases within each set, but from Volume 4 onwards all the discs are packed into a plastic case with flip disc holders. The entire series has been released over a total of 20 volumes, the first 16 volumes featuring eight discs each but Volume 17 onwards contains ten discs. The UK DVD releases are a combination of two volumes as released in Australia. For example, the UK Volume 1 consists of the Australian Volumes 1 and 2. As with the Australian versions of the DVDs, the episodes are on the whole uncut, but due to the aged source of the master tapes, sometimes minor edits are made to the episodes to cover breaks in the picture or sound.{{cite web|url=http://canberrang.webng.com/prisoner/dvd/cuts.htm |title=List of cuts made to the DVDs |work=canberrang.webng.com |accessdate=10 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813032023/http://canberrang.webng.com/prisoner/dvd/cuts.htm |archivedate=13 August 2011 |df= }} "The Edna Pearson Story", released on UK DVD in February 2010, contains most of the previously cut scenes although, episode 470 is still missing a scene. ==VHS== ===United States=== The first 12 episodes of ''Prisoner: Cell Block H'' were over six VHS tapes in the United States in 1993 via [[MPI Media Group|MPI Home Video]] {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; text-align:center;" |- ! Title ! Release date ! Season ! Rating ! Additional information |- | ''Episodes 1 & 2'' | 23 June 1993 | Season 1 | Not rated | |- |- | ''Episodes 3 & 4''{{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/6302786851| title=Prisoner Cell Block H Vol 2 [VHS] | publisher=amazon.com| date=| accessdate=November 8, 2014}} | 23 June 1993 | Season 1 | Not rated | |- | ''Episodes 5 & 6'' | 23 June 1993 | Season 1 | Not rated | |- | ''Episodes 7 & 8'' | 23 June 1993 | Season 1 | Not rated | |- | ''Episodes 9 & 10''{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/6302787092| title=Prisoner Cell Block H Vol 5 [VHS] | publisher=amazon.com| date=| accessdate=November 8, 2014}} | 23 June 1993 | Season 1 | Not rated | |- | ''Episodes 11 & 12''{{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/6302787106| title=Prisoner Cell Block H Vol 6 [VHS] | publisher=amazon.com | date=| accessdate=November 8, 2014}} | 23 June 1993 | Season 1 | Not rated | |} ===United Kingdom=== NTV Entertainment released eight VHS tapes between 1993 and 1995 in the United Kingdom. {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; text-align:center;" |- ! Title ! Release date ! Season ! Rating ! Additional information |- | ''Episodes 1 & 2'' | 1993 | Season 1 |  '''15'''  | |- | ''Episodes 3 & 4'' | 1993 | Season 1 |  '''PG'''  | |- | ''Episodes 5 & 6'' | 1993 | Season 1 |  '''PG'''  | |- | ''Episodes 7 & 8'' | 1 February 1994 | Season 1 |  '''15'''  | |- | ''Episodes 9 & 10'' | 15 August 1994 | Season 1 |  '''PG'''  | |- | ''Episodes 11 & 12'' | 7 November 1994 | Season 1 |  '''PG'''  | * Exclusive interview footage with members of the cast |- | ''Episodes 326 & 327'' | 11 October 1993 | Season 4, episode 80 &
Season 5, episodes 1 |  '''15'''  | |- | ''The Great Escape'' | 10 April 1995 | {{n/a}} |  '''E'''  (Exempt from classification) | ''On the Outside Tour 1990''; the cast of ''Prisoner'' on tour |} * All episodes from the VHS releases have been re-rated  '''12'''  for the DVD releases in United Kingdom. ==DVD== ===Compilation releases=== {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"|Title ! colspan="3"|Initial release ! rowspan="2"|Episodes ! rowspan="2"|No. of discs ! rowspan="2"|Additional information |- ![[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] ![[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] ![[DVD region code#4|Region 4]] |- | The Best Of (1) | 30 November 2004{{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0003JANTG| title=Prisoner Cell Block H, Set 1 (25th Anniversary Collector's Edition)| publisher=[[Amazon.com]]| date=| accessdate=2015-07-18}} | 22 September 2003{{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0000AV3GP| title=Prisoner Cell Block H - Best Of Prisoner Cell Block H [DVD] [1987]| publisher=[[Amazon.co.uk]]| date=| accessdate=2015-07-18}} | 18 February 2002{{cite web| url=http://www.blu-ray.com/dvd/Prisoner-DVD/52680/| title=Prisoner DVD| publisher=Blu-ray.com| date=| accessdate=2015-07-18}} | 12 | 3 | {{Hidden|{{align|left|Features}}| * Disc 1 - ''The Early Years'': episodes 166, 287, 327 & 400 * Disc 2 - ''The Terrorist Siege'': episodes 550, 551, 550 & bonus episode 536 * Disc 3 - ''The End'': episodes 600, 601, 691 & 692 * Released as ''25th Anniversary Collector's Edition'' in United States * Also released on VHS format in Australia * '''Special features:''' ** Interviews with [[Val Lehman]] (Bea Smith), [[Anne Phelan]] (Myra Desmond) & casting director [[Jan Russ]] ** Clean End Credit Sequence ** Photo Gallery - 100 Unseen Continuity Polaroids *Ratings: ** '''Not Rated''' (U.S.) ** '''15''' (UK) ** '''M''' (Australia) (also released as individual discs in Australia) * '''Region 2 re-release:''' 21 October 2013{{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00EZM31CI| title=The Best of Prisoner Cell Block H [DVD] | publisher=[[Amazon.co.uk]]| date=| accessdate=2015-07-18}} * '''Region 4 re-release:''' 4 December 2013{{cite web| url=http://www.dvdorchard.com.au/194719/the-best-of-prisoner-cell-block-h-australian-tv-on-dvd| title=The Best Of Prisoner Cell Block H on DVD | publisher=dvdorchard.com.au| date=| accessdate=2015-07-18}} }} |- | The Best Of (2) | 19 December 2006{{cite web| url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000HDR8A0| title=Prisoner Cell Block H, Set 2| publisher=[[Amazon.com]]| date=| accessdate=2015-07-18}} | {{N/a|TBA}} | 24 February 2003{{cite web| url=http://www.blu-ray.com/dvd/Prisoner-DVD/101089/| title=Prisoner DVD Prisoner: Cell Block H / The Best of - Volume 2| publisher=Blu-ray.com| date=| accessdate=2015-07-18}} | 12 | 3 | {{Hidden|{{align|left|Features}}| * Disc 1 - ''The Beginning'': episodes 1, 2, 3 & 4 * Disc 2 - ''The Great Escapes'': episodes 20, 165, 471 & 598 * Disc 3 - ''A Not So Quiet Riot'': episodes 247, 248, 586 & 667 * Released as ''Set 2'' in United States * Also released on VHS format in Australia * '''Special features:''' ** Photo Gallery ** Post Cards *Ratings: ** '''Not Rated''' (U.S.) ** '''M''' (Australia) (also released as individual discs in Australia) (special features on region 4 only) }} |- | The Best Of (3) | {{N/a|TBA}} | {{N/a|TBA}} | 26 July 2004{{cite web| url=http://www.blu-ray.com/dvd/Prisoner-DVD/101090/| title=Prisoner DVD Prisoner: Cell Block H / The Best of - The complete series was released through 20 volumes containing 32 episodes per set for the first sixteen volumes; Volume 17 contains 40 episodes, Volume 18 and Volume 19 both contain 48 episodes and the final volume contains 44 episodes. The reason for the increased number of episodes on later sets was due to the fact that Fremantle wanted to keep exactly double the amount of episodes as the original Australian sets. The first 33 Australian releases contain 16 episodes per set; sets 34 to 39 containing 24 episodes per set and Volume 40 containing 20 episodes. Therefore, Fremantle in the UK doubled-up on episodes so that they could finish releasing by Volume 20. In Australia, distribution company [[Shock Records]] began releasing the UK volumes in 2011, as their original volumes are now out of print. The final volume was released in early 2014. {| class="wikitable" style="width:95%; text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"|Title ! colspan="2"|Release date ! rowspan="2"|Season ! rowspan="2"|Episodes ! rowspan="2"|No. of discs ! colspan="2"|Rating ! rowspan="2"|Additional information |- ! This is a '''list of [[Amphitheatre#Modern amphitheatres|amphitheatres]]''' in use today.
[[File:Hearst Greek Theater graduation.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Hearst Greek Theatre]] during graduation in 2002]] [[File:Arlington National Cemetery Amphitheater.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Arlington Memorial Amphitheater]] has been the site of numerous [[Memorial Day]] and [[Veterans Day]] ceremonies, as well as hosting the funerals of many famous Americans.]] [[Image:Red Rock Amphitheatre Seatings.jpg|thumb|300px|A view of the seating at [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre]]]] [[Image:P13jul59.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Nikon at Jones Beach Theater]] is right on the water. This aerial photo is from 1959.]] [[File:Libertypk1.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Highmark Amphitheatre at Liberty Park]] is all open grass seating, with a covered stage that is right at the edge of the water.]] [[File:SPACInterior.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Saratoga Performing Arts Center]] is an open-air amphitheatre, but has a roof and two stories of seating.]] [[Image:Dalhalla overview.JPG|thumb|300px|The [[Dalhalla]] Amphitheatre is located in a former [[limestone]] quarry in Sweden.]] [[File:Waldbuehne Berlin 2007 002.jpg|thumb|300px|[[WaldbÃ¼hne]] during a performance by [[Barbra Streisand]], summer 2007]] [[Image:Cemil Topuzlu AÃ§Ä±khava Tiyatrosu.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Cemil Topuzlu Open-Air Theatre]] in [[Istanbul]], Turkey before the [[Loreena McKennitt]] concert on 13 June 2009]] [[Image:Levitt shell.jpg|thumb|300px|Elvis Presley gave his first paid concert at the [[Levitt Shell]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]].]] [[File:Starlight Theatre stage Kansas City MO.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Starlight Theatre (Kansas City, Missouri)|Starlight Theatre]] in Kansas City, Missouri]] [[File:Theatre_of_Epidaurus_OLC.jpg|thumb|300px| The 4th-century BC [[Ancient Theatre of Epidaurus|Ancient Theatre of]] [[Epidaurus]] still functions today as an open-air amphitheatre for ancient Greek [[Greek tragedy|tragedy]] and [[Ancient Greek comedy|comedy]] performances as well as for modern theatrical performances.]] [[File:Clemson University Outdoor Theater and Cooper Library.jpg|300px|thumb|Outdoor Theater and Cooper Library at [[Clemson University]].]]

{{Infobox Convention |name=Midwest Gaming Classic |image=[[File:Midwest Gaming Classic (logo).png|250px]] |caption= |status=Active |genre=[[Video game|Video gaming]] |venue=Sheraton Milwaukee Brookfield Hotel |location=[[Brookfield, Wisconsin]] |country=United States |first=June 30, 2001 |last= |organizer= |filing= |attendance=1,600+ (2007)
10,000+ (2015) |website=http://www.midwestgamingclassic.com/ }} The '''Midwest Gaming Classic''' ('''MGC''') is an annual convention for all forms of electronic entertainment, including [[video games]], arcade games and pinball, with a focus on [[retrogaming]]. The event has been held in several locations in Wisconsin since launching in 2001. == History == The Midwest Gaming Classic was first held on June 30, 2001 as '''Jagfest 2K1''' and was dedicated to ongoing fan base and [[homebrew (video games)|homebrew]] scene of the [[Atari Jaguar]]. At that time, the 2K1 show organizers Dan Loosen and Gary Heil decided to open the show to all classic platforms in an effort to expand attendance. They were soon contacted by Martin Goldberg who offered to set up a museum area for the show, and started a tradition of having consoles and computers on display playable by show attendees, as well as gaming competitions held on multiple platforms and prizes at the show.{{Cite web|title = Midwest Gaming Classic - Past Shows Main Page|url=http://www.midwestgamingclassic.com/content.php?id=past|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080520084419/http://www.midwestgamingclassic.com/content.php?id=past|date=March 29, 2008|archivedate = 2008-05-20|accessdate = 2015-07-28}} That first year had 15 tables and 20 games available to play. By 2015, it had grown to over one thousand games.{{Cite web|title = Milwaukee hosts a gathering of gamers at the Midwest Gaming Classic|url = http://fox6now.com/2015/04/11/milwaukee-hosts-a-gathering-of-gamers-at-the-midwest-gaming-classic/|website = FOX6Now.com|accessdate = 2015-07-28}} The event has moved several times over the years, but has always been in the Milwaukee area. == Events == The Midwest Gaming Classic has a focus on retrogaming, but displays modern game systems as well. The devices on display range from the newest gaming devices to some of the oldest, such as the original [[Pong]]. The event also attracts video game champions from the past.{{Cite web|title = Gamers in their glory|url = http://www.jsonline.com/news/waukesha/29564904.html|accessdate = 2015-07-28|first = Dani|last = McClain}} The event is known for its pinball games, gaming museum and modern game tournaments. It also has a display of gaming systems that never had success due to a superior competitor or change in technology. Nearly all game systems on display can be played by attendees.{{Cite web|title = Invasion of the classics|url = http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/29556679.html|accessdate = 2015-07-28|first = Stanley A.|last = Miller II}} ==History== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Date !! Location !! Attendance !! Notes |- | 2001 || PieperPower Center, Milwaukee || < 100 || MGC began as JagFest 2k1. {{cite web|last1=Hamari|first1=Alan|title=Trade show a playground for 'geeks' of all stripes|url=http://archive.brookfieldnow.com/news/89482002.html|website=Brook Field Now|accessdate=23 March 2009}} |- | 2002 || PieperPower Center, Milwaukee || 100+ || It was rebranded as Midwest Classic a name it retained for another year. |- | 2003 || Nicolet High School, Glendale || 200 || The location of the venue was changed. |- | 2004 || Brookfield Sheraton, Glendale || 1,500 || The show was rebranded as Midwest Gaming Classic. The venue was once again changed. |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.midwestgamingclassic.com/ Midwest Gaming Classic] - official site. *[https://www.facebook.com/MGCgaming/ Facebook Page] {{Video Game Trade Shows}} [[Category:Recurring events established in 2001]] [[Category:Video game trade shows]] [[Category:Video gaming in the United States]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Olive Borden | image = Olive Borden Stars of the Photoplay.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = {{birth date|1906|7|14}} | birth_place = [[Richmond, Virginia]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1947|10|1|1906|7|14}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], California, U.S. | resting_place = [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Glendale]] | yearsactive = 1924â1934 | spouse = {{marriage|Theodore Spector|1931|1932|end=annulled}}
{{marriage|John Moeller|1934|1941|end=divorced}} }} '''Olive Borden''' (July 14, 1906 â October 1, 1947) was an American film and stage actress who began her career during the [[silent film]] era. She was nicknamed "[[The Joy Girl]]",{{harv|Liebman|200|p=323}} after playing the lead in the 1927 [[The Joy Girl|film of that same title]].{{cite book |last1=Lowe |first1=Denise |title=An Encyclopedic Dictionary of Women in Early American Films: 1895-1930 |date=2014 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=9781317718963 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68e2AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1899&dq=%22Olive+Borden%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwihpbL5k-TdAhVIeawKHfLvDOYQ6AEIOjAD#v=onepage&q=%22Olive%20Borden%22&f=false |accessdate=1 October 2018 |language=en}} Borden was known for her jet-black hair and overall beauty. At the peak of her career in the mid-1920s, Borden was earning $1,500 a week. In 1927, she walked out on her contract with [[20th Century Fox#Fox Film Corporation|Fox]] after refusing to take a pay cut. By 1929, her career began to wane due to her reputation for being temperamental and her difficulty transitioning to sound films. She made her last film, ''[[Chloe, Love Is Calling You]]'', in 1934 and moved on to stage work for a time. By the late 1930s, she had declared bankruptcy and stopped acting. During [[World War II]], she joined the [[Women's Army Corps|WAC]]s. She was later honorably discharged after sustaining a foot injury and attempted to make a comeback in films. However, Borden's attempts to get back into acting were hindered by her alcoholism and health problems. In 1945, she began working at the [[Casa de Rosas|Sunshine Mission]], a home for destitute women located in the [[skidrow]] section of Los Angeles. She died there in October 1947 of a stomach ailment and [[pneumonia]] at the age of 41. ==Early life== Olive Borden was born in [[Richmond, Virginia]] on July 14, 1906. Her birth name was often reported erroneously as Sybil Tinkle until the 1990s when it was discovered that another woman with the same name had been confused with Borden.{{harv|Lowe|2005|p=76}} Borden's father died when she was a baby and she was raised by her mother, Sybil ("Sibbie"), in [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]] and [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]] where she also attended [[Catholic]] boarding schools.{{harv|Shipman Springer|1974|p=273}} She was a distant relative of [[Lizzie Borden]].{{harv|Brettell|2005|p=35}} As a teenager, she persuaded her mother to take her to Hollywood to pursue a career in show business. To support themselves they opened a candy store and Olive worked as a telephone operator. ==Career== Borden began her career as one of the [[Mack Sennett#Sennett Bathing Beauties|Sennett Bathing Beauties]] in 1922 and was soon appearing as a vamp in [[Hal Roach]] comedy shorts. Producer [[Paul Bern]] chose her for an uncredited role in his film ''[[The Dressmaker from Paris]]'' (1925). She was signed by [[20th Century Fox#Fox Film Corporation|Fox]] after being named a [[WAMPAS Baby Stars|WAMPAS Baby Star]] in 1925 (along with cousin [[Natalie Joyce]]).{{cite news |title=WAMPAS Choice Proves Open Sesame |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23683307/wampas_1927_selection/ |work=The Los Angeles Times |date=January 23, 1927 |location=California, Los Angeles |page=42|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 30, 2018}} {{Open access}} Borden quickly became one of their most popular and highest paid stars earning a salary of $1,500 a week. She had starring roles in eleven films at Fox including ''[[3 Bad Men]]'' and ''[[Fig Leaves]]'', both costarring her then-boyfriend [[George O'Brien (actor)|George O'Brien]]. During this time she worked with some directors who would go on to achieve major fame, including [[John Ford]], [[Howard Hawks]], and [[Leo McCarey]]. When Fox cut her salary in 1927, she walked out on her contract. By this point she was a major star but she found it difficult to make the transition from silent films to [[Sound film|"talkies"]]. She worked to get rid of her [[Southern American English|Southern accent]] but could not overcome her reputation as being difficult. She was still in demand as an actress, and continued to work for [[Columbia Pictures|Columbia]] and [[RKO Pictures|RKO]]. Borden cut her trademark hair into a short bob and turned herself into a modern [[flapper]]. She made several movies in the early 1930s but her career stalled. Her last screen credit came in 1934 in the film ''Chloe, Love Is Calling You''. She moved to New York where she had a brief stage career and made a living on the [[vaudeville]] circuit. ==Later years== During her acting career, Borden was one of the highest paid stars. She spent her money freely and by the late 1930s, she was broke. Borden then found work as a postal clerk and mail carrier and also worked as a nurse's aide.{{harv|Ankerich|2010|p=74}} In 1942, Borden joined the [[Women's Army Corps (United States Army)|WAC]] where she received an army citation for bravery in turning over an enemy ammunition truck. Her Army career ended after she was hospitalized in [[Walter Reed Medical Center]] with a severe foot injury. After her [[honorable discharge]] she attempted an unsuccessful comeback in films. Borden struggled with alcoholism and numerous health problems. She spent her final years in the [[skid row]] section of [[Los Angeles]] scrubbing floors at the Sunshine Mission, a home for destitute women. ==Personal life== Borden had several relationships with men in and out of the motion picture industry. For the majority of her life, she lived with her mother, Sibbie. From 1926 to 1930, Borden was romantically involved with actor [[George O'Brien (actor)|George O'Brien]] and the press reported they were engaged. She also dated director [[Marshall Neilan]], producer [[Paul Bern]], and had a long affair with Arthur Benline, Lieutenant Commander in the Navy Construction Battalion. Borden was married twice. Her first marriage was to stockbroker Theodore Spector, whom she married on March 28, 1931, in Harrison, New York.{{cite news |title=Olive Borden Has Marriage Annulled |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24177141/olive_borden/ |work=Star Tribune |agency=Associated Press |date=November 22, 1932 |location=Minnesota, Minneapolis |page=13|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 30, 2018}} {{Open access}} The marriage was rocky{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} and the couple separated in early 1932. Borden learned after their separation that Spector was not divorced from his first wife, Pearl, whom he married in 1919. Spector was arrested for [[bigamy]] in 1932 after his first wife came forward and claimed they were still married. In November 1932, Borden petitioned the court for an annulment, which was granted on November 22, 1932. She married her second husband, railroad technician John Moeller, in November 1934.{{harv|Ankerich|2010|pp=72â73}} That marriage ended in divorce seven years later. ==Death== Olive Borden died on October 1, 1947 from a stomach ailment and [[pneumonia]] at the age of 41.{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Olive Borden, Star Of Silent Films, 40 |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9806E0D61731E13BBC4A53DFB667838C659EDE|quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=October 2, 1947 |accessdate=2014-12-06 }} The only possession she had when she died was a signed photo of herself.{{harv|Klepper|1999|p=358}} Borden's funeral was held on October 3 at the Sunshine Mission home for girls where she had worked and lived since 1945.{{cite news |title=Olive Borden, 40, Once Famous Movie Star, Dies in Poverty |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/24177361/olive_borden/ |work=The Nebraska State Journal |agency=Associated Press |date=October 2, 1947 |location=Nebraska, Lincoln |page=6|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 30, 2018}} {{Open access}} The mission's founder, Essie Binkley West, officiated the service.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=50RQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PQ0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3724,3734256&dq=olive+borden&hl=en|title=Simple Funeral for Olive Borden|date=October 5, 1947|work=The Milwaukee Sentinel|page=15|accessdate=December 20, 2012}} Borden was buried at [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]] in [[Glendale, California]].{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Funeral of Olive Borden |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9901E0D9133CE13BBC4E53DFB667838C659EDE |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=October 6, 1947 |accessdate=2014-12-06 }} Her mother was interred in the grave next to her. For her contributions to the film industry, Borden has a [[List of actors with Hollywood Walk of Fame motion picture stars|motion pictures star]] on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] at 6801 [[Hollywood Boulevard]].{{cite web|url=http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/olive-borden/|title=Hollywood Star Walk: Olive Borden|publisher=latimes.com|accessdate=20 December 2012}} She was one of the first eight stars chosen to receive a star in 1958.{{cite web|url=http://www.walkoffame.com/pages/history |title=Hollywood Walk of Fame - History |website=walkoffame.com |publisher=Hollywood Chamber of Commerce |accessdate=November 29, 2017}} ==Selected filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
