{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}}
{{Culture of Argentina}} [[File:Patogame.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[Pato]] is the national sport in Argentina.]] The practice of '''sports in Argentina''' is varied due to the population's diverse European origins and the mostly mild climate. [[Association football]] is the most popular discipline and other sports played both professionally and recreatively [[athletics (sport)|athletics]], [[auto racing]], [[basketball]], [[boxing]], [[cycling]], [[field hockey]], [[fishing]], [[golf]], [[Team handball|handball]], [[mountaineering]], [[padel tennis]], [[polo]], [[Roller hockey (Quad)|roller hockey]], [[Rowing (sport)|rowing]], [[rugby union]], [[Sailing (sport)|sailing]], [[skiing]], [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[tennis]] and [[volleyball]]. Argentine achievements can be found in team sports such as association football, basketball, field hockey and rugby union, and individual sports such as boxing, golf, tennis and rowing. [[Pato]], the national sport, is not very popular.
[[Argentina]] is one of the most important sport powers in the region, ending at the top of the medal count at the [[South American Games]] since 1978, with exceptions in 2002 and 2010. In the all-time medal table of the [[Pan American Games]], Argentina holds first place among South American countries and fourth place in the Americas, behind the [[United States]], [[Canada]] and [[Cuba]]. Despite a relative lack of success at the Olympic level in more traditional sports like athletics, swimming, and [[gymnastics]], Argentina has had successful participations in other sports like association football, basketball, field hockey, roller hockey, padel tennis, polo and rugby union.
==Auto racing== From [[Rallying]] to [[Formula One]], auto racing is a sport followed by a number of fans in Argentina. Formula One legend [[Juan Manuel Fangio]] was five times [[Formula One]] world champion under four different teams, winning 102 of his 184 international races, and is widely ranked as the greatest driver of all time.{{sfnm|1a1=Nauright|1a2=Parrish|1y=2012|1p=98|2a1=Dougall|2y=2013|2pp=170â171}} Other distinguished racers were [[Oscar Alfredo GÃ¡lvez]], [[Juan GÃ¡lvez]], [[JosÃ© FroilÃ¡n GonzÃ¡lez]], and [[Carlos Reutemann]].{{sfnm|1a1=Arbena|1y=1999|1p=147|2a1=Dougall|2y=2013|2pp=170â171, 195}} Years after Fangio's career was over, [[Carlos Reutemann]] was the best known Argentine driver of the 1970s. More recently [[JosÃ© MarÃ­a LÃ³pez]] has emerged as one of the world's top [[touring car racing|touring car]] drivers, winning the [[World Touring Car Championship]] in 2014, 2015 and 2016. Argentine competitions include the [[TC 2000]] and [[Turismo Carretera]] [[road racing]] series, as well as [[Rally Argentina]] of the [[World Rally Championship]]. Argentina has also hosted the [[2009 Dakar Rally|2009]], [[2010 Dakar Rally|2010]], [[2011 Dakar Rally|2011]], [[2012 Dakar Rally|2012]], [[2013 Dakar Rally|2013]] [[2014 Dakar Rally|2014]], [[2015 Dakar Rally|2015]], [[2016 Dakar Rally|2016]], [[2017 Dakar Rally|2017]] and [[2018 Dakar Rally|2018]] editions of the [[Dakar Rally]]. Former events include the defunct Formula One [[Argentine Grand Prix]] and [[World Sportscar Championship]]'s [[1000 km Buenos Aires]].
==Football== {{Main article|Football in Argentina}} [[File:Arg vs urug 1927.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Argentina playing against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in [[1927 South American Championship|1927]]. The ''ClÃ¡sico del RÃ­o de la Plata'' is one of the oldest derbies in the world.]]
[[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Argentina and part of the country's culture. The sport is played by children during breaks at school and by grown-ups on the plenty of both [[futsal|indoor]] and outdoor fields located throughout the country.
The [[Argentina national football team|national team]] has won the [[FIFA World Cup]] twice (in [[1978 FIFA World Cup|1978]] and [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]]), successive [[Summer Olympics|Olympic]] gold medals (in [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics â Men's tournament|2004]] and [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics â Men's tournament|2008]]), fourteen [[Copa AmÃ©rica|Copas AmÃ©rica]], one [[FIFA Confederations Cup|Confederations Cup]] and six [[FIFA U-20 World Cup|World Youth Championships]]. Argentine clubs have won the [[Copa Libertadores]], the top continental competition, a record 22 times and the [[Intercontinental Cup (football)|Intercontinental Cup]] or [[FIFA Club World Cup]] 8 times, a record shared with Brazilian clubs. The [[Argentine Primera DivisiÃ³n]] is the top level domestic competition. The country's most famed football idol is [[Diego Maradona]]. Actually the most famous football player is [[Lionel Messi]].
Argentina's fiercest rival is [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] and their rivalry is sometimes known as the "[[Argentina and Brazil football rivalry|Battle of the South Americans]]". They have played each other numerous times in the Copa AmÃ©rica and the Confederations Cup, and their clubs have met several times in the Copa Libertadores finals. Argentina is one of the few national teams in association football that have beaten Brazil on a regular basis. Argentine and Brazilian national youth teams have also met at various tournaments. At the [[2008 Summer Olympics]], the under-23 teams met in the [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics â Men's tournament#Semi-finals|semi-finals]], with Argentina winning 3â0 in a hard-fought game. In addition, the aforementioned Maradona has been often compared with Brazilian iconic player [[PelÃ©]].
[[Women's association football|Women's football]] is far behind in terms of popularity and professionalism. However, the [[Argentina women's national football team|women's national team]] has competed in the [[South American Women's Football Championship|South American Championship]] since 1995, finishing as runner-up three times before winning the competition in [[2006 South American Women's Football Championship|2006]] with a 5â0 victory over [[Brazil women's national football team|Brazil]]. The national team also played in the [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup|2003]] and the [[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup]]s, but they finished last in the group on both occasions.
==Basketball== [[Basketball]] is a very popular sport, mostly in the [[provinces of Argentina]]. The Basketball Clubs' Association organizes the [[Liga Nacional de BÃ¡squet]], the top level league in the country. Although the [[Argentina national basketball team|National team]] won the first [[FIBA Basketball World Cup|FIBA World Championship]] in [[1950 FIBA World Championship|1950]], the sport did not gain country-wide popularity until the 2000s, when the national team conquered the Olympic gold medal at the [[Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics â Men's tournament|2004 Summer Olympics]] and had a good performance in the [[2002 FIBA World Championship|2002]], [[2006 FIBA World Championship|2006]] and [[2010 FIBA World Championship|2010 World Championships]] finishing on the second, fourth and fifth position respectively. The national team also won the bronze medal at the [[Basketball at the 2008 Summer Olympics â Men's tournament|2008 Summer Olympics]]. Argentine [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] star [[Manu GinÃ³bili]] also won NBA Championship rings in 2003, 2005, 2007 and 2014 as a member of the [[San Antonio Spurs]], the 2007 victory included his compatriot [[Fabricio Oberto]].
The National team has won the [[2001 Tournament of the Americas]] and the [[2011 FIBA Americas Championship]].
Although [[women's basketball]] is not professional in Argentina, the national team participates in most international competitions, reaching their highest point at the [[2006 FIBA World Championship for Women]] where they finished in the 9th place.
==Rugby union== {{Main article|Rugby union in Argentina}}
[[File:Argentina vs England 2011 RWC (1).jpg|thumb|right|250px|Argentina facing [[England national rugby union team|England]] at the [[2011 Rugby World Cup]].]] [[Rugby union]] is a popular and largely amateur sport. However, despite this amateurism, the [[Argentina national rugby union team|national team]] have become one of the most powerful in the sport, finishing third in the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]] and rising as high as third in the [[World Rugby Rankings]] (then known as the IRB World Rankings) immediately after. Since November 2004, Argentina have picked up at least one win over all the participants in Europe's [[Six Nations Championship]], drawn with the [[British and Irish Lions]] and narrowly lost to the [[New Zealand national rugby union team|All Blacks]], who were forced to survive a last-second assault on their try line. In particular, the ''Pumas'' have enjoyed a dominating record in recent years against [[France national rugby union team|France]], going 7â2 since 2000, with a total points against of 7.
For the first 20 years of the sport's professional era, dating from 1996, most important Argentine players have emigrated to [[Europe]] (mainly to England and France). Probably the best known players are 1970s and 1980s star [[Hugo Porta]]; [[AgustÃ­n Pichot]], Pumas captain during their 2007 World Cup run and now the vice chairman of [[World Rugby]]; his successor as captain, [[Felipe Contepomi]]; current star utility back [[Juan MartÃ­n HernÃ¡ndez]]; 1990s star and later Pumas head coach [[Santiago Phelan]]; [[Marcelo Loffreda]], who coached the team during their 2007 World Cup run before leaving to take up the coaching post at [[English Premiership (rugby union)|English club]] power [[Leicester Tigers]]; and current head coach [[Daniel Hourcade]].
In 2012, Argentina joined New Zealand, Australia and South Africa in the Tri Nations Championship, which then became [[The Rugby Championship]]. In 2014, Argentina took their first victory in this competition against Australia in the first round. Argentina further cemented its links with [[SANZAAR]] when the country was added to that body's [[Super Rugby]] competition, which added teams based in [[Jaguares (Super Rugby)|Argentina]] and [[Sunwolves|Japan]] in 2016.
==Tennis== [[File:Nalbandian signing autographs at 2006 Australian Open.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[David Nalbandian]] and fans at the [[2006 Australian Open]].]] {{Main article|Tennis in Argentina}}
[[Tennis]] has been quite popular among people of all ages since the 1970s, after both [[Guillermo Vilas]] and later [[Gabriela Sabatini]] in the 1980s reached the number 2 position and won several [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slams]]. Even though no Argentine player has thus far reached the first place at the [[ATP Rankings]], many Argentines have been among the most important in the circuit. During the 2000s a number of Argentine players were among the top 10 and the [[2004 French Open]] featured an all-Argentine final. [[GastÃ³n Gaudio]] won the [[French Open|Roland Garros]] in 2004. At the [[2005 Tennis Masters Cup]], [[David Nalbandian]] defeated world number 1 [[Roger Federer]] and the tournament gathered 4 Argentine players, an all-time record for any nationality. Most recently, [[Juan MartÃ­n del Potro]] has emerged as one of the leading players in the world, having won the [[2009 US Open (tennis)|2009 US Open]] a few days before his 21st birthday. Argentina has won the [[World Team Cup]] four times, in 1980, 2002, [[2007 ARAG World Team Cup|2007]] and [[2010 ARAG World Team Cup|2010]] and has reached the semifinals of the [[Davis Cup]] 7 times in the last 10 years, losing the finals against Russia in [[2006 Davis Cup|2006]] and Spain in [[2008 Davis Cup|2008]] and [[2011 Davis Cup|2011]]; the Argentine team also played the final in [[1981 Davis Cup|1981]], where they lost against the United States. The national squad won the [[2016 Davis Cup]].
==Field hockey== [[File:Las Leonas 2008 (completo).jpg|thumb|left|300px|''Las Leonas'', the women's national team.]] The [[Argentina women's national field hockey team|women's national team ''Las Leonas'']] is one of the world's most successful, with four Olympic medals, two [[Women's Hockey World Cup|World Cups]], a [[FIH Hockey World League|World League]] and seven [[Hockey Champions Trophy|Champions Trophy]].{{sfn|Nauright|Parrish|2012|p=11}} The national team won the [[Women's Hockey World Cup|World Cup]] in [[2002 Women's Hockey World Cup|2002]] and [[2010 Women's Hockey World Cup|2010]]. At the Olympic Games, it won the silver medal in [[Field hockey at the 2000 Summer Olympics#Women's tournament|2000]] and [[Field hockey at the 2012 Summer Olympics â Women's tournament|2012]], as well as bronze in [[Field hockey at the 2004 Summer Olympics â Women's tournament|2004]] and [[Field hockey at the 2008 Summer Olympics â Women's tournament|2008]]. ''Las Leonas'' also won the annual [[Hockey Champions Trophy|Champions Trophy]] on seven occasions, in [[2001 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy|2001]], [[2008 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy|2008]], [[2009 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy|2009]], [[2010 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy|2010]], [[2012 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy|2012]], [[2014 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy|2014]] and [[2016 Women's Hockey Champions Trophy|2016]] and the [[FIH Hockey World League|World League 2014-2015]]. [[Luciana Aymar]] is recognized as the best female player in the history of the sport,<ref name=hwc1>{{cite web|url=http://www.rabobankhockeyworldcup2014.com/video/meet-luciana-aymar-las-leonas-argentina|title=Meet Luciana Aymar â Las Leonas (Argentina)|publisher=Rabobank Hockey World Cup 2014|place=Nieuwegein, The Netherlands|year=2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140616131926/http://www.rabobankhockeyworldcup2014.com/video/meet-luciana-aymar-las-leonas-argentina|archivedate=16 June 2014|deadurl=yes|access-date=6 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> being the only player to have received the [[FIH Player of the Year Awards|FIH Player of the Year Award]] eight times.<ref name=fih1>{{cite web|url=http://www.fih.ch/en/news-4873-amazing-aymar-lands-eighth-fih-player-of|title=Amazing Aymar lands eighth FIH Player of the Year crown|publisher=FIH â ''FÃ©dÃ©ration Internationale de Hockey sur Gazon'' [International Hockey Federation]|place=Lausanne, Switzerland|date=8 December 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131212013213/http://www.fih.ch/en/news-4873-amazing-aymar-lands-eighth-fih-player-of|archivedate=12 December 2013|deadurl=no}}</ref>
The [[Argentina men's national field hockey team|men's national team ''Los Leones'']] won the gold medal at the [[Field hockey at the 2016 Summer Olympics#Men's tournament|2016 Summer Olympics]] and the bronze medal at the [[2014 Men's Hockey World Cup|2014 World Cup]] and [[2008 Men's Hockey Champions Trophy|2008 Champions Trophy]]. The national squad also won [[Field hockey at the Pan American Games|Pan American Games]] on nine occasions and the [[2005 Men's Hockey Champions Challenge|2005]], [[2007 Men's Hockey Champions Challenge|2007]] and [[2012 Men's Hockey Champions Challenge|2012]] [[Hockey Champions Challenge|Champions Challenges]].
==Rink hockey== [[Rink hockey]] is mainly played in the [[Cuyo (Argentina)|Cuyo]] region (especially in [[San Juan Province (Argentina)|San Juan Province]]). Argentine players have an international quality, with the men's national team winning five [[Rink Hockey World Championship]] titles. The women's national team is the world's most successful team, having won five titles.
==Boxing== :''For a list of Argentine boxers, see [[:Category:Argentine boxers]]'' [[File:Firpo saca a Dempsey-Radiofoto del GrÃ¡fico.jpg|thumb|[[Luis Firpo]] throws [[Jack Dempsey]] out of the ring in 1923; this was the basis for artist [[George Wesley Bellows]]' famous portrait.]]
[[Pascual PÃ©rez (boxing)|Pascual PÃ©rez]] was Argentina's first world boxing champion. There are Argentine boxing legends such as [[Carlos MonzÃ³n]], [[Horacio Accavallo]], [[Santos Laciar]], [[Juan MartÃ­n Coggi]] and [[Nicolino Locche]] who held the world champion's title in their categories. Argentine boxers have, as of 2004, earned 24 Olympic medals, including seven gold medals.
Argentine boxer [[Victor Galindez]] was the third [[Latin American]] to win the world's Light-Heavyweight title (after [[Puerto Rico]]'s [[JosÃ© Torres]] and [[Venezuela]]'s [[Vicente Rondon]], [[World Boxing Association|WBA]]-recognized champion during the middle of the 1970s). Galindez died after he was run over by a car during an [[auto racing]] competition in which he took part.
In 1994, WBA world Middleweight champion [[Jorge Castro (boxer)|Jorge Castro]] knocked out [[John David Jackson (boxer)|John David Jackson]] in the ninth round to retain his title in [[Monterrey, Mexico]]. Since Castro was on the brink of suffering a technical knockout loss when he won the fight, the punch with which he beat Jackson has become known as boxing's version of Diego Maradona's [[Hand of God goal]].
[[Marcela AcuÃ±a]] is a world champion [[Women's boxing|female boxer]], and arguably one of the most popular fighters of the 2000s in Argentina.
Other fighters, such as [[Oscar Bonavena]], [[Juan RoldÃ¡n]], and [[Luis Firpo]], did not win world championships, but were also popular among boxing fans during their years as professional fighters.
On 17 April 2010, [[Sergio Gabriel MartÃ­nez|Sergio MartÃ­nez]] outpointed American [[Kelly Pavlik]] in [[Atlantic City]] to become the lineal [[Middleweight]] champion of the world.
[[Marcos RenÃ© Maidana]] has also been champion in 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012.
==Padel tennis== [[Padel tennis]] is played by four and a half million amateur players in thirty five thousand courts; it is the most participated sport in Argentina. Professional players compete in National Circuit of tournaments. Argentina won 17 titles at the [[Padel Tennis World Championship]] (between women and men).
==Polo== [[File:Campeonato Argentino de Polo 2010 - 5236515585 2b8cb412de o.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Campeonato Argentino Abierto de Polo|Argentine Polo Open Championship]].]] Argentina's [[polo]] team won their first Olympic gold medal in [[Polo at the 1924 Summer Olympics|1924]] and the second gold medal in [[Polo at the 1936 Summer Olympics|1936]]. [[Adolfo Cambiaso]], [[Gonzalo Pieres]], his brother [[Facundo Pieres|Facundo]], the Novillo Astrada brothers, the Heguy's, and Tommy Iriarte are currently ranked amongst the best polo players in the world. The three most important polo tournaments in the world, the [[Campeonato Argentino Abierto de Polo|Argentine Open]], the [[Hurlingham Club (Argentina)|Hurlingham Open]], and the Tortugas Open are held in [[Argentina]]. Historically, Argentina has always been a leading country in this sport, and has been uninterrupted world champions since 1949 and Argentine players comprise most of the world's top ten players. Argentina has won five [[World Polo Championship]].
==Golf== Among the best in South America, the first prominent figure of this sport in Argentina was [[JosÃ© Jurado]]. He was the first Argentine to travel to major international championships and is thus often credited as the "Father of Argentine Professional Golf".<ref>[[Al Barkow|Barkow, Al]] "Hail Hispana" ''PGA Professionals Guide to Travel''. 7 June 2008. Retrieved 29 October 2008 from http://www.pgaprofessionalsguide.travel/page/725-31174.htm?travel_article_id=6465&section=followingthetour{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Other notable Argentine golfers include [[Roberto De Vicenzo]], [[Antonio CerdÃ¡]], [[JosÃ© CÃ³ceres]], [[Eduardo Romero]], [[Ãngel Cabrera]], [[AndrÃ©s Romero]] and [[Ricardo GonzÃ¡lez (golfer)|Ricardo GonzÃ¡lez]]. De Vicenzo and CerdÃ¡ won the [[World Cup (men's golf)|1953 Canada Cup]]. In history, Argentine golfers won three Majors, [[Roberto De Vicenzo]] the [[The Open Championship|British Open]] in [[1967 Open Championship|1967]], and Ãngel Cabrera the [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] in [[2007 U.S. Open Golf Championship|2007]] and the [[Masters Tournament|Augusta Masters]] in [[2009 Masters Tournament|2009]].
==Sailing== Argentina won 10 Olympic medals in [[Sailing (sport)|sailing]] (1 gold, 4 silver, 5 bronze), the Argentinian experience and level in this sport is high, even between young children competing in optimist class boats. [[Carlos EspÃ­nola (sailor)|Carlos EspÃ­nola]] is the sailor who won most Olympic medals in this sport with four. [[Santiago Lange]] won the World Championship on four occasions (1985, 1993, 1995 and 2004) and the gold medal at the [[2016 Summer Olympics]].
==Handball== Although handball in Argentina lacks the popularity of this sport on the European continent, both in terms of infrastructure and federated players, the Handball is a firmly growing sport in Argentina with the [[Argentina national handball team|men's national team]] regularly qualifying for the World Championship. Argentina has started producing world class talent, such as the brothers [[Diego Simonet|Diego]] and [[SebastiÃ¡n Simonet]].
The [[Argentina national handball team|Men's national handball team]] won the gold medal at the [[2011 Pan American Games]] and seven [[Pan American Men's Handball Championship|Pan American Handball Championships]].
==Volleyball== [[Volleyball]] has a professional male league. [[Argentina men's national volleyball team|Argentina national volleyball team]]'s best achievements are the [[Argentina at the 1988 Summer Olympics#Bronze|bronze medals]] at the [[Volleyball at the 1988 Summer Olympics|1988 Summer Olympics]] and [[1982 FIVB Volleyball Men's World Championship]]. The male team is usually [[FIVB World Rankings|ranked]] by the [[FÃ©dÃ©ration Internationale de Volleyball|FIVB]] among the top 10 national teams in the world.
The national team also won the gold medal at the [[Volleyball at the Pan American Games|Pan American Games]] in two occasions (1995, 2015).
Female volleyball is not played professionally. The [[Argentina women's national volleyball team|female team]] is less important internationally than its male counterpart.
==Cricket== {{Main article|Cricket in Argentina}} [[File:Buenosaires cricketclub rosariocc 1916.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Buenos Aires Cricket & Rugby Club|Buenos Aires C.C.]] and [[Club AtlÃ©tico del Rosario|Rosario C.C.]] players posing together during a game, 1916.]] [[Cricket]] has been played in Argentina since 1806, with the [[Argentina national cricket team|international side]] making its first appearance in 1868, against the Uruguay national team. The sport regained some popularity, due to the national team's participation at the [[World Cricket League]], and the [[Argentina national women's cricket team]] at the Women's version of the [[ICC Americas Championship]]. Though cricket is a minor sport, Argentina is the strongest team in mainland South America, and are currently playing in division 1777 of the World Cricket League. There is a huge scope of development of the sport in this country, given that there are a large number of British descendants in Argentina. Argentina dominated the South American Cricket Championship. {{clear}}
==Olympic Games== {{Main article|Argentina at the Olympics}} Argentina was one of eight founding members of the [[International Olympic Committee]], and first participated in the [[Olympic Games]] in [[1900 Summer Olympics|1900]] with one single athlete. Argentine Olympic competitors have, from 1900 to 2016, garnered 74 medals (21 gold, 25 silver, 28 bronze); from 1924 to 1952, its athletes had good showings, giving the Argentine delegations global ranks of between 16th and 19th. From 1956 to 2000, however, Argentina did not win any gold medals, a situation that was reversed in [[2004 Summer Olympics|2004]], when it acquired two and further so, in [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008]], [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012]] and [[2016 Summer Olympics|2016]].
On 4 July 2013, [[Buenos Aires]] was selected as host city for the [[2018 Summer Youth Olympics]].<ref>[http://www.olympic.org/news/buenos-aires-elected-as-host-city-for-2018-youth-olympic-games/202222 Buenos Aires elected as Host City for 2018 Youth Olympic Games]</ref>

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=December 2014}}
{{Infobox video game |width= 264px |title= Street Legal Racing: Redline |image= |caption= |developer = [[Invictus Games (company)|Invictus Games]] |publisher= [[Activision Value]] |designer= |series= ''[[Street Legal (game)|Street Legal]]'' |engine= Custom-made [[Java_class_file|java]] script, Invictus SCX |released= Windows: July 18, 2003 |genre= [[Racing video game|Racing]] |modes= [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms= [[Microsoft Windows]] }}
'''''Street Legal Racing Redline''''' is a racing game developed by [[Invictus Games (company)|Invictus]] and published by [[Activision Value]]. The game was released for Windows in July 2003.
On September 9, 2014, Invictus announced via their Facebook page that the ''Street Legal'' franchise, as well as every other game Invictus had developed using that game engine was now [[abandonware]], and the engine, along with all the art assets, were for sale.<ref>https://www.facebook.com/invictusgames/posts/845125675521524</ref>
==Gameplay== {{original research section|date=October 2018}} The game takes place in Valo City (possibly a play on the word "[[velocity]]"), a metropolis known for its vast underworld of [[illegal street racing]]. The plot of the game is to beat every club and accomplish the requirements to enter the Race of Champions, a prestigious racing competition where one can win a bonus car. Players have to race others on the streets during the day for prestige (respect) or money to customize the car. During the night, players can either participate in a drag race against another driver or watch the race. And also the newly added race tracks that allows the player to race their own vehicles against AI's on a race track to win a prize.
A unique feature of the game is its detailed level of customization for the vehicles. The player can buy a completely new car from the dealership, a used one from a local shop where they were already customized or even [[totaled]], or build the car from scratch with a chassis. Unlike a traditional street racing video game if the player crashes their car the consequences are very real and must ''manually'' replace each part that got destroyed in the crash.
==Patches==
Currently, there are three patches for the game: the 2.2.1 MWM (by Miran & Wichur), 2.3.0 Live Edition (by Raxat) and SLRR2015 (by Bigg Boss93, available on VStanced.com<ref>[http://vstanced.com/ Vstanced.com]</ref>). The latest version (2.3.1) was released on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and is gradually improved by the Russian game developer ImageCode in collaboration with Raxat.
==Mods==
Thousands of mods were made for this game, including vehicles, parts for said vehicles, tracks (Some mods only work on the 2.2.1 MWM version), sounds, menu interfaces, and textures. Because some of the versions of the game are highly unstable, it is highly likely to crash when too many mods are installed mainly on the 2.2.1 and 2.3.0 versions.
==Reboot==
Thanks to [[fundraising|public funding]], the game was greenlit and eventually re-released on Steam on May 7th, 2016. The Steam release was very unstable when it first launched, but is gradually improving. Its textures and interface make it more contemporary, and the career is altered for more of a challenge.
==Possible sequel== Dave Singh, the owner of streetlegalmods.com, made a deal with Invictus Games, Ltd. stating that if the Kickstarter crowdfunding campaign reached a minimum of $150,000, the development of the sequel to ''SLRR'', ''Street Tuning Evolution'', would officially begin, as long as the game was playable and the community was allowed to add content. $500,000 was demanded to make a complete game.
After having a bad launch with the Kickstarter, and due to the popular demand of a PayPal option, Invictus Games, Ltd. and Dave Singh decided to move the campaign to IndieGogo to solve the many problems, and also to extend the deadline. Backers could then use PayPal to make a pledge. The campaign would have been funded only if it had reached $150,000. The IndieGogo campaign had a significantly better launch than the Kickstarter campaign, which raised around $24,000 a little more than 40 days after its launch in December 18, 2014. The IndieGogo campaign raised nearly $10,000 just one day after its launch. Unfortunately the campaign failed, reaching just over $30,000.
Despite the failure, another person, Bartosz "Wichur" Bieszka, plans to make a sequel to this game under the "Car Tune" title. ImageCode LLC is also working on a similar project also being called [http://image-code.com/2018/10/24/news-on-street-tuning-evolution/ Street Tuning Evolution] which means the game is still very much alive<ref>http://image-code.com/2018/10/24/news-on-street-tuning-evolution/</ref> which will be a sequel to Street Legal Racing Redline.
== References == <references />

Peter Adams | music = | cinematography = [[Russell Boyd]] | editing = Trevor Ellis | distributor = Network 7 | studio = [[Reg Grundy Productions]] | released = 1978 | runtime = 74 mins | country = Australia | language = English | budget = A$105,000 }} '''''The Alternative''''' is a 1978 Australian television film about an unmarried editor of a woman's magazine who finds herself pregnant. She has a relationship with another woman.Ed. Scott Murray, ''Australia on the Small Screen 1970â1995'', Oxford Uni Press, 1996 p5-6 At the Annual Penguin Awards, given by the Television Society of Australia, the film was awarded best Actress (Wendy Hughes), Actor (Peter Adams) and Supporting Actor (Alwyn Kurts), as well as Best Adult Drama.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article110876606 |title=TV's Penguin Awards. |newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]] |date=7 November 1977 |accessdate=14 July 2013 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}} == Cast == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Wendy Hughes]] as Melanie Hilton * [[Peter Adams (actor)|Peter Adams]] as Noel Denning * Carla Hoogeveen as Linda * [[Tony Bonner]] as Peter * [[Alwyn Kurts]] as Doherty * Ken Goodlet as Melanie's Father * [[Betty Lucas]] as Melanie's Mother * [[Anne Haddy]] as Helen * Mary Mackie as Mrs. Millbank * Jackie Rees as June {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0258408/ ''The Alternative''] at [[IMDB]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Alternative}} [[Category:Australian television films]] [[Category:Australian films]] {{Australia-tv-film-stub}}

{{more citations needed|date=December 2014}} {{Italic title}} {{Infobox film | name = The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin | image = The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | film name = | director = [[Wenn V. Deramas]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Vincent del Rosario * Veronique del Rosario-Corpus }} | writer = | screenplay = {{Plainlist| * Keiko Aquino * Danno Kristoper Mariquit * Wenn V. Deramas }} | story = {{Plainlist| * Kriz Gazmen * Danno Kristoper Mariquit * Keiko Aquino }} | based on = | starring = [[Vice Ganda]]
[[Richard Yap]]
[[Tom Rodriguez]]
[[Alex Gonzaga]]
[[Bimby Aquino Yap|Bimby Aquino-Yap]] | narrator = | music = [[Vincent de Jesus]] | cinematography = Elmer Despa | editing = Marya Ignacio | studio = [[ABS-CBN Film Productions, Inc.|ABS-CBN Film
Productions, Inc.]]
[[Viva Films]] | distributor = [[Star Cinema]]
[[Viva Films]] | released = December 25, 2014 | runtime = 105 minutes | country = [[Philippines]] | language = Filipino
English | budget = | gross = â±455 million {{cite web | url=http://www.pds.com.ph/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/Disclosure-No.-998-2016-Presentation-Materials-re-Investors-Briefing-on-the-First-Quarter-2016-Financial-and-Operating-Results.pdf |title=ABS-CBN 1Q 2016 Investorâs Briefing Presentation Materials| publisher=''[[ABS-CBN]]'' | date=12 May 2016 | accessdate=27 June 2016 }} ({{USD|9 million}})}} '''''The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin''''' is a 2014 [[comedy film]] written and directed by [[Wenn V. Deramas]]. It is the sequel to ''[[The Unkabogable Praybeyt Benjamin]]''. The film is one of the official entries to the [[40th Metro Manila Film Festival]]. [[Vice Ganda]] reprised his role as Colonel Benjamin "Benjie" Santos VIII with [[Richard Yap]], [[Tom Rodriguez]], [[Bimby Yap]] and introducing [[Alex Gonzaga]] with the special participation of [[Eddie Garcia]]. == Plot == After defeating the terrorists led by Billy Aladdin, the once humble Private Benjamin ([[Vice Ganda]]) has become the Philippines' unkabogable soldier and a worldwide sensation. One day in the military headquarters, the zombies came to attack the terrorist and Benjamin must face them using vegetable attack (ala [[Plants Vs. Zombies|PVZ]]). Inevitably, he rises from the ranks and in no time becomes the incredible, unbeatable, and unreachable soldier and promoted to Colonel. To prepare him better, Benjamin is assigned under a new general, Wilson Chua ([[Richard Yap]]). However, Private Benjamin committed a big mistake. Benjamin is about to be dismissed from service when Gen. Wilson Chua saves him by giving him a mission â to be the private security of a brat kid Bimbee ([[Bimby Yap]]). As he watches over Bimbee, Benjamin finds himself clashing with Misty (Rhed Bustamante), General Chua's daughter, and the meddlesome housemaid Gundina ([[Alex Gonzaga]]). However, as he gets to know Bimbee more, he learns that Bimbee is a kid deprived of love from family â something that he has ignored in his quest to be on top again. Will he succeed in his new mission? Terrorists led by Jan Jaranjan ([[Tom Rodriguez]]) threaten the government to detonate the bomb hidden in a mall. How would Benjamin and Wilson deal with it? In most action scenes in the sequel, they are referencing various video games and mobile app games such as Plants VS Zombies when Benjie and his friends are fighting against the zombies in Paris using gardening weapons, Just Dance when Benjie and his friends as well as General Wilson Chua and company does performing the moves in order to stop the bomb from detonating, Crisis Zone where Benjie and his friends fought Jan Janranjan and his men using machine guns used in the arcade games and the Street Fighter series when Benjie defeats Jan Jaranjan using a parody version of Ryu's Tatsumaki Sempukyaku in three hits. ==Cast of characters== *[[Vice Ganda]] as Colonel Benjamin "Benjie" Santos VIII *[[Richard Yap]] as Commanding General "Wilson" Chua *[[Tom Rodriguez]] as Janjaranjan *[[Bimby Aquino]]-Yap as Bimbee Pineda Chua *[[Alex Gonzaga]] as Gundina Galamiton *[[Al Tantay]] as Benjamin "Bino" Santos VII *[[Eddie Garcia]] as Gen Benjamin "Ben" Santos VI *[[Vandolph|Vandolph Quizon]] as Buhawi Manay *[[Nikki Valdez]] as Lucresia Alcantara *[[Kean Cipriano]] as Emerson Ecleo *[[Anja Aguilar]] as Jesamine Santos *[[DJ Durano]] as Dominador "Dondi" Rosales *Ricky Rivero as Big Boy Carnate *[[Dennis Padilla]] as Bentot Santos *[[Malou de Guzman]] as Lilibeth Santos *Abby Bautista as Anjemin Santos *Rhed Bustamante as Misty Chua * Gerard Garcia as Inspector Bautista * Kurt Ong as Inspector Realado *David Licauco as Terrorist ===Special guest appearance=== *Ms. [[Angel Locsin]] as young Lilibeth Santos (Guest) *[[Kris Aquino]] as Krissy (Guest) *Darla Sauler as Darla (Guest) *[[Luis Manzano]] as young Benjamin "Ben" Santos VII (Guest) *[[James Reid (entertainer)|James Reid]] as James (Guest). Boy _pugante == Reception == === Box office === [[Metro Manila Development Authority|MMDA]] Chairman [[Francis Tolentino]], revealed that ''The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin'' topped the box office record of the [[40th Metro Manila Film Festival]]'s opening day on December 25, 2014 in a radio interview in DZMM. ''Praybeyt Benjamin'' was ahead of fellow entrants, ''[[My Big Bossing's Adventures]]'' and ''[[Feng Shui 2]]'' ranked second and third respectively in terms of box office record on the opening day of the film festival. Tolentino did not state the official figures of the sales on the opening day of the film festival during the said interview.{{cite news|last1=Corales|first1=Nestor|title=âPraybeyt Benjaminâ tops MMFF opening day|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/159255/praybeyt-benjamin-tops-mmff-opening-day|accessdate=1 January 2015|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=26 December 2014}} During her stint at ''[[The Buzz (talk show)|The Buzz]]'' where is she is one of the hosts, Kris Aquino said that ''The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin'' recorded P172 million worth of box office receipts as of 3:00 pm [[Philippine Standard Time|PST]] December 28, 2014.{{cite news|title='Praybeyt Benjamin,' 'Feng Shui' earn P260M in 4 days|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/12/28/14/praybeyt-benjamin-feng-shui-earn-p260m-4-days|accessdate=1 January 2015|publisher=ABS-CBN News|date=29 December 2014}} In the January 15, 2015 episode of Vice Ganda's variety show, [[It's Showtime (variety show)|It's Showtime]], he announced that the movie closed the day before with P435 million earnings, surpassing the film [[Starting Over Again (film)|Starting Over Again]] in terms of domestic earnings. He now hold the distinction of starring in 7 of the 20 [[List of highest-grossing films in the Philippines|highest-grossing films in the Philippines of all time]]. === Critical response === Despite being a high-grossing film at the [[40th Metro Manila Film Festival]], reception for ''The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin'' has received mixed to negative reviews.{{cite news|last1=Balbin|first1=Sherwin Allan|title=The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin Tops MMFF 2014 & Earns P172 Million In 4 Days!|url=http://www.philippineedition.com/2014/12/the-amazing-praybeyt-benjamin-tops-mmff.html|accessdate=1 January 2015|publisher=Philippine Edition|date=29 December 2014}} Zig Marasigan of Rappler, described the film in his movie review as "a brainless, hyper-stylized and utterly ridiculous family comedy". Marasigan criticized ''Praybeyt Benjamin'' for "unashamedly made for profit". He also described the film as "cheap, tacky and absolutely nonsensical. But say what you might about the film's level of intellectualism (or lack thereof), it is at least honest about its intentions". Marasigan however acknowledged that the film fulfilled its purpose, to primarily entertain its target audience.{{cite news|last1=Marasigan|first1=Zig|title=[MMFF 2014] âPraybeyt Benjamin 2' Review: Show me the money|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/movies/79142-mmff-2014-praybeyt-benjamin-2-review-vice-ganda|accessdate=1 January 2015|publisher=Rappler|date=27 December 2014}} Bubbles Salvador at the [[Philippine Entertainment Portal]], has a more positive review for the film. While Salvador took note of one loophole in the plot of the film - namely the lack of resolution between Bimbee and his father, with the former feeling unloved by the latter, Salvador described Praybeyt Benjamin 2 as "worth of one's couple of hours at the cinema this holiday season, if one is not looking for a lesson in history, a love story, or a good scare, and would settle for a light and funny action comedy".{{cite news|last1=Salvador|first1=Bubbles|title=MMFF 2014 REVIEW: The Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin|url=http://www.pep.ph/guide/movies/15345/mmff-2014-review-the-amazing-praybeyt-benjamin|accessdate=1 January 2015|publisher=Philippine Entertainment Portal|date=28 December 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amazing Praybeyt Benjamin, The}} [[Category:2014 films]] [[Category:Philippine Christmas films]] [[Category:Philippine comedy films]] [[Category:Philippine fantasy films]] [[Category:Philippine films]] [[Category:Philippine sequel films]] [[Category:Star Cinema films]] [[Category:Viva Films films]] [[Category:Films set in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Films directed by Wenn V. Deramas]] [[Category:Sequel films]]

{{Infobox song | title = The Crabfish | English_title = | image = Lobster (PSF).png | image_size = | caption = | alt = | original_artist = | recorded_by = | performed_by = | written = | Released = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | Published = c. 1620 | Length = <!-- {{Duration|m=MM|s=SS}} --> | Writer = Traditional | Composer = | Lyricist = | Language = English }} "'''The Crabfish'''" is a [[ribaldry|ribald]] [[humorous]] [[folk song]] of the [[England|English]] [[oral tradition]]. It dates back to the seventeenth century, appearing in [[Bishop Percy's Folio]] Manuscript as a song named "The Sea Crabb" based on an earlier tale.<ref name=SeaCrabb1867>{{cite book |title=Bishop Percy's Folio Manuscript: loose and humorous songs |editor=Frederick J. Furnivall |location=London |year=1867|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jLo_AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA100&dq=bishop%20percy%27s%20folio%20manuscript%20crabfish&pg=PA100#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=100}}</ref> The [[moral]] of the story is that one should look in the [[chamber pot]] before using it.
Owing to the indelicate nature of its theme this ballad was intentionally excluded from [[Francis James Child]]'s renowned compilation of folk songs ''The English and Scottish Popular Ballads''.<ref>[http://mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=15048 Lyr Req: Mr Radalum? / Raddle-um / Crabfish etc.]</ref> The song has a [[Roud Folk Song Index]] of 149.
==Synopsis==
A man brings a crabfish (most likely a [[Homarus gammarus|common lobster]]) home as a gift for his wife and puts it in the chamber pot. Some time in the night his wife answers [[excretion|a call of nature]] and the crustacean grabs her private parts. In the ensuing scuffle the husband gets bitten too.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collections.mun.ca/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/munfla_list&CISOPTR=4854&CISOBOX=1&REC=3|title=The Crabfish|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref>
==Variants== "Johnny Daddlum" is the [[List of Irish ballads|Irish version]] of this song.<ref>[http://mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=123881 Johnny Daddlum]</ref> There are variants in which the [[vulgarity|coarse language]] is more clear-cut than in others. In some variants the wife is [[pregnant]], having previously told her husband about her [[food craving|craving]] to eat crabfish meat.
This song has also variants under other names such as "Old She-Crab," "The Crayfish," "A Combat Between an Ale-Wife and a Sea Crab," "The Fishy Crab," and "The Lobster."<ref>[http://mudcat.org/@displaysong.cfm?SongID=4437 Old She-Crab]</ref><ref>[http://mudcat.org/@displaysong.cfm?SongID=6105 The Crayfish]</ref><ref>[http://mudcat.org/thread.cfm?threadid=3854 A Combat Between an Ale-Wife and a Sea Crab]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armadillo.net/llewtrah/lobster-song.html|title=Lobster Song|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref>
==Text== The Crayfish
{{poemquote|Fisherman, fisherman, standing by the sea Have you got a crayfish that you can sell to me By the way side high diddly aye do
Yes sir, yes sir, that indeed I do I have got a crayfish that I can sell to you By the way side high diddly aye do
Well, I took the crayfish home, and I though he'd like a swim So I filled up the chamber pot, and I threw the bugger in By the way side high diddly aye do
In the middle of the night, I thought I'd have a fit When my old lady got up to a-have a shit By the way side high diddly aye do
Husband, husband, she cried out to me The devil's in the chamber pot, and he's got hold of me By the way side high diddly aye do
Children, children, bring the looking glass Come and see the crayfish that bit your mother's arse By the way side high diddly aye do
Children, children, did you hear the grunt Come and see the crayfish that bit your mother's cunt By the way side high diddly aye do
It's the ending of me story; I don't have any more I've an apple in me pocket, and you can have the core By the way side high diddly aye do}}
==Versions== A [[expurgation|sanitized]] version of "The Crabfish," expunging the straightforwardness of the original in order to make the song available for child audiences, was released in recent years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.giamusic.com/products/P-6535.cfm|title=The Crabfish|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> Instead of private parts the crabfish grabs the wife by the nose and the husband by the ear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://brookwoodelementary.com/teacher_sites/music/Lyrics/Crabfish.html|title=The Crabfish|publisher=|accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{citation |url=http://www.saltydick.com/lyrics/12-the-crabfish.htm |title=Salty Dick's Uncensored Sailor Songs, "The Crabfish"|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211014749/http://www.saltydick.com/lyrics/12-the-crabfish.htm |accessdate=2014-06-08 |archivedate=2012-12-11}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eYL8cJOrDYA Dan and Bonnie Milner sing "The Crabfish" at the 2009 Chicago Maritime Festival] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KRhsfcMxPrs Tom Chapin sings "The Crabfish Song" (children version)] {{Francis James Child}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Crabfish, The}} [[Category:English folk songs]] [[Category:Irish folk songs]] [[Category:Ethnic humour]] [[Category:Excretion]] [[Category:Year of song unknown]] [[Category:Songwriter unknown]] [[Category:Songs about animals]]

{{other uses|Inspiration (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox album | name = The Inspiration | type = Studio album | artist = [[Jeezy]] | cover = The Inspiration.jpg | alt = | released = December 12, 2006 | recorded = 2006 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | length = | label = {{flatlist| *[[Corporate Thugz|CTE]] *[[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]]}} | producer = {{flatlist| *Jeezy (also [[Executive producer#Music|exec.]]) *Demetrius "Kinky B" Ellerbee (exec.) *[[L. A. Reid|Antonio "L.A." Reid]] (exec.) *Kevin "Coach K" Lee (co-exec.) *Shakir Stewart (co-exec.) *[[J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League]] *[[DJ Toomp]] *[[Cool & Dre]] *[[Timbaland]] *[[Don Cannon]] *[[The Runners]] *[[Mr. Collipark]] *[[Shawty Redd]] *[[The Hitmen (production team)|Anthony Dent]] *[[Drumma Boy]] *[[Midnight Black]] *Key Pushas}} | prev_title = [[Let's Get It: Thug Motivation 101]] | prev_year = 2005 | next_title = [[The Recession]] | next_year = 2008 | misc = {{Singles | name = The Inspiration | type = Album | single1 = [[I Luv It (Young Jeezy song)|I Luv It]] | single1date = November 2, 2006 | single2 = [[Go Getta]] | single2date = January 21, 2007 | single3 = [[Dreamin' (Young Jeezy song)|Dreamin{{'}}]] | single3date = April 6, 2007 }} }} '''''The Inspiration''''' (abbreviation for '''''The Inspiration: Thug Motivation 102''''') is the second [[studio album]] by American rapper [[Jeezy]]. It was released on December 12, 2006, by [[Corporate Thugz|Corporate Thugz Entertainment]] (CTE), and [[Def Jam Recordings]]. ''The Inspiration'' was supported by three [[Single (music)|single]]s: "[[I Luv It (Young Jeezy song)|I Luv It]]", "[[Go Getta]]" featuring [[R. Kelly]], and "[[Dreamin' (Young Jeezy song)|Dreamin']]" featuring [[Keyshia Cole]]. ==Singles== The album's lead [[Single (music)|single]], "[[I Luv It (Young Jeezy song)|I Luv It]]", was released on November 2, 2006. The song was [[Hip hop production|produced]] by [[DJ Toomp]].{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUjfWwqFcFI |title=Young Jeezy - I Luv It |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160327094251/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wUjfWwqFcFI |archivedate=2016-03-27 |df= }} The album's second single, "[[Go Getta]]", was released on January 21, 2007. The song features a [[guest appearance]] from American [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] singer [[R. Kelly]], while the production was handled by the duo [[The Runners]].{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C7ec0VI4Yl0 |title=Young Jeezy - Go Getta ft. R. Kelly |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310122122/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C7ec0VI4Yl0 |archivedate=2016-03-10 |df= }} The album's third single, "[[Dreamin' (Young Jeezy song)|Dreamin']]", was released on April 6, 2007. The song features a guest appearance from American R&B singer [[Keyshia Cole]], while the production was also handled by The Runners.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=srSuX08b5nw |title=Young Jeezy - Dreamin' ft. Keyshia Cole |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-06-16 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151220201626/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=srSuX08b5nw |archivedate=2015-12-20 |df= }} ==Commercial performance== The album debuted at number one on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], selling 352,000 copies in the first week, making it Young Jeezy's first number-one album in his career.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/56396/young-jeezy-hicks-enter-atop-the-billboard-200 |title=Young Jeezy, Hicks Enter Atop The Billboard 200 |publisher=Billboard |date=2006-12-20 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030064604/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/56396/young-jeezy-hicks-enter-atop-the-billboard-200 |archivedate=2015-10-30 |df= }} In 2009, the album has sold 1,229,000 copies in the United States.{{cite web |author=Navjosh |url=http://hiphop-n-more.com/2009/10/xxl-scans-def-jams-entire-discography-record-sales/ |title=XXL Scans: Def Jamâs Entire Discography & Record Sales |publisher=HipHop-N-More |date=2009-10-18 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160903153309/http://hiphop-n-more.com/2009/10/xxl-scans-def-jams-entire-discography-record-sales |archivedate=2016-09-03 |df= }} ==Critical reception== {{Album ratings |MC = (70/100){{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-inspiration/young-jeezy/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for The Inspiration |publisher=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309181842/http://www.metacritic.com/music/the-inspiration/young-jeezy/critic-reviews |archivedate=2016-03-09 |df= }} |rev1 = [[AllMusic]] |rev1score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web |author=Andy Kellman |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-inspiration-thug-motivation-102-mw0000778280 |title=The Inspiration: Thug Motivation 102 - latimes |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2006-12-18 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222130635/http://articles.latimes.com/2006/dec/18/entertainment/et-albums18 |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }} |rev3 = ''[[HipHopDX]]'' |rev3score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/album-reviews/id.730/title.young-jeezy-the-inspiration |title=Young Jeezy - Young Jeezy's "The Inspiration" |publisher=Rapreviews.com |date=2006-12-12 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924123117/http://www.rapreviews.com/archive/2006_12F_inspiration.html |archivedate=September 24, 2015 |df= }} |rev8 = ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' |rev8score = {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/12688271/review/12811381/the_inspiration |title=The Inspiration : Young Jeezy : Review : Rolling Stone |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2006-12-12 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070918214017/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/12688271/review/12811381/the_inspiration |archivedate=September 18, 2007 }} |rev9 = ''[[USA Today]]'' |rev9score = {{Rating|3|4}}{{cite web|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/USAToday/access/1178600531.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Dec+12%2C+2006&author=Edna+Gundersen%3BSteve+Jones%3BBrian+Mansfield%3BKen+Barnes&pub=USA+TODAY&edition=&startpage=D.6&desc=Listen+up |title=Listen up |publisher=Pqasb.pqarchiver.com |date=2006-12-12 |accessdate=2015-12-10}} |rev10 = ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]'' |rev10score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/reviews/2007/01/young-jeezy-the-inspiration/ |title=Young Jeezy The Inspiration - XXL |publisher=Xxlmag.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222154450/http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/reviews/2007/01/young-jeezy-the-inspiration/ |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }} }} The album has a score of 70 out of 100 from [[Metacritic]] based on "generally favorable reviews". ''[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]'' gave the album four stars out of five and stated that "Despite its frustratingly uniform theme--coke--and Jeezy's inflexible, one-speed rasp, his sophomore effort, ''The Inspiration'', suggests that last year's victories were no fluke." ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave it a B and stated that Young Jeezy "spits snowman raps with rough-hewn charisma and unseemly enthusiasm."{{cite web|last=Rabin |first=Nathan |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/music-in-brief,22568/ |title=Music in Brief Â· Article Â· The A.V. Club |publisher=Avclub.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-10}} ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' gave it three stars out of four and said that Jeezy "continues to improve, crafting songs that are distinctive and memorable, even if he sticks to the well-worn topics of rims, clothes and clubbing."{{cite web |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-12-12/news/0612120465_1_young-jeezy-snippets-nimble |title=Young Jeezy THE INSPIRATION RATING: 3 SOUND... |publisher=Articles.chicagotribune.com |date=2006-12-12 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222150055/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-12-12/news/0612120465_1_young-jeezy-snippets-nimble |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }} ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' gave it three-and-a-half stars and said that "the smallest suggestions of personality make a charismatic impact." ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' gave the album seven out of ten and stated that "This time around, it's as if the script has been reshot by Michael Bay--glossy and viscerally stimulating--and we're watching a coming attraction for a film that never starts." ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' gave it a positive review and said that Jeezy's lyrics "have matured past coke-slinging to the drug's effect on his life." ''[[The Phoenix (newspaper)|The Phoenix]]'' gave it two-and-a-half stars out of four and said that "Fortunately, getting the money isnât all this follow-up to last yearâs breakthrough ''Letâs Get It'' cares about, and the singles here are fire."{{cite web |author=MATTHEW GASTEIER |url=http://thephoenix.com/Boston/music/29987-young-jeezy-the-inspiration/ |title=Young Jeezy - CD Reviews |publisher=Thephoenix.com |date=2006-12-19 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222155724/http://thephoenix.com/Boston/music/29987-young-jeezy-the-inspiration/ |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }} Other reviews are average or mixed: [[Okayplayer]] gave it an average review and stated, "''The Inspiration'', an even darker work than the debut, finds the Snowman weaving paranoid street tales with eerie trunk-rattling beats. The albumâs main downside is the repetitive nature of many of the tracks."{{cite web |url=http://www.okayplayer.com/reviews/young-jeezy-200612124903.html |title=Young Jeezy |publisher=Okayplayer.com |date=2006-01-02 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222121253/http://www.okayplayer.com/reviews/young-jeezy-200612124903.html |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }} ''Prefix Magazine'' gave it a score of six out of ten and called it "Spottily effective gangster posturing."{{cite web |author=Amos Barshad |url=http://www.prefixmag.com/reviews/young-jeezy/the-inspiration-thug-motivation-102/15802/ |title=Album Review: Young Jeezy - The Inspiration: Thug Motivation 102 |publisher=Prefixmag.com |date=2008-03-05 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222082541/http://www.prefixmag.com/reviews/young-jeezy/the-inspiration-thug-motivation-102/15802/ |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }} However, ''[[Stylus Magazine]]'' gave it a Câ and said, "The strange thing about ''The Inspiration'' is how it's posited as an alternative to the much-bullied "conscious rap," and yet, it's among the least fun albums released this year."{{cite web |url=http://stylusmagazine.com/reviews/young-jeezy/the-inspiration.htm |title=Young Jeezy - The Inspiration - Review |publisher=Stylus Magazine |date= |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304112839/http://stylusmagazine.com/reviews/young-jeezy/the-inspiration.htm |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }} ''[[The New York Times]]'' gave it a mixed review and said, "Young Jeezyâs appeal was never his writing, but now words sometimes fail him." ''[[Hartford Courant]]'' also gave it a mixed review and said that "Almost every dramatic synth swell, exploding snare and multi-tracked "Yeaaahhhh" has been done better elsewhere."{{cite web |url=http://articles.courant.com/2006-12-14/entertainment/0612140201_1_thug-motivation-def-jam-atlanta-s-young-jeezy |title=New On Disc - tribunedigital-thecourant |publisher=Articles.courant.com |date=2006-12-14 |accessdate=2015-12-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223110123/http://articles.courant.com/2006-12-14/entertainment/0612140201_1_thug-motivation-def-jam-atlanta-s-young-jeezy |archivedate=2015-12-23 |df= }} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | extra_column = Producer(s) | title1 = Hypnotize (Intro) | writer1 = {{flat list| *[[Jeezy|Jay Jenkins]] *[[Shawty Redd|Demetrius Stewart]]}} | extra1 = [[Shawty Redd]] | length1 = 3:41 | title2 = Still on It | writer2 = {{flat list| *Jenkins *[[Midnight Black|Tracey Sewell]]}} | extra2 = [[Midnight Black]] | length2 = 3:46 | title3 = U Know What It Is | writer3 = {{flat list| *Jenkins *Stewart}} | extra3 = Shawty Redd | length3 = 3:44 | title4 = J.E.E.Z.Y. | writer4 = {{flat list| *Jenkins *Stewart}} | extra4 = Shawty Redd | length4 = 3:49 | title5 = [[I Luv It (Young Jeezy song)|I Luv It]] | writer5 = {{flat list| *Jenkins *[[DJ Toomp|Aldrin Davis]]}} | extra5 = [[DJ Toomp]] | length5 = 4:00 | title6 = [[Go Getta]] | writer6 = {{flat list| *Jenkins *[[The Runners|Andrew Harr]] *[[The Runners|Jermaine Jackson]] *[[R. [[NBCUniversal Television Distribution]] | channel = [[Broadcast syndication|Syndication]] | first_aired = {{Start date|1988|10|08}} | last_aired = {{End date|1991|05|25}} | preceded_by = ''[[The Munsters]]'' }} '''''The Munsters Today''''' is an American [[sitcom]] and [[sequel]] to the original 1964â66 sitcom ''[[The Munsters]]'' that aired in [[broadcast syndication|syndication]] from October 8, 1988 to May 25, 1991.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/guide/articles/m/munsterstodaythe_7774620.shtml |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050301084415/http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/guide/articles/m/munsterstodaythe_7774620.shtml |archivedate=2005-03-01 |title=BBC â Comedy Guide â The Munsters Today |website=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2016-04-15}}{{cite news|title= Bright Mood Makes New `Munsters` A Bore|work= Chicago Tribune|date=1988-10-08|url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-10-08/entertainment/8802060029_1_munsters-today-howard-morton-herman-munster|accessdate=2010-10-10|first=Gary|last=Dretzka}} ==Plot== The series concerns the day-to-day life of a family of benign monsters, with married couple Herman Munster (Frankenstein's monster) and Lily Munster (a vampire). Lily's Father, Grandpa, who is also a vampire, lives with the family. Herman and Lily have a son, Eddie, who is a werewolf, and their niece, Marilyn, also lives with them. ==Cast== ===Main cast=== [[File:The Munsters Today.jpg|thumb|200px|The cast of "The Munsters Today."]] * [[John Schuck]] â [[Herman Munster]] * [[Lee Meriwether]] â [[Lily Munster]] * [[Jason Marsden]] â [[Eddie Munster|Edward "Eddie" Wolfgang Munster]] * [[Hilary Van Dyke]] â [[Marilyn Munster]] * [[Howard Morton]] â [[Grandpa (The Munsters)|"Grandpa" Vladimir Dracula]] ===Recurring cast=== * [[Mary Cadorette]] â Dee Dee Nelson * [[Richard Steven Horvitz]] â Howie Buchanan * [[Greg Mullavey]] â Roger Nelson * [[Scott Reeves]] â Dustin Nelson ===Special guest stars=== {{colbegin}} * [[Kaye Ballard]] â [[Mother Nature]] * [[Billy Barty]] â Genie * [[Shelley Berman]] â Sam Hawkins * [[Jonathan Brandis]] â Matt Glover * Dr. [[Joyce Brothers]] â Mrs. Cousins * [[Ruth Buzzi]] â Dracula's Mother * [[Gordon Cooper]] â Himself * [[Bill Daily]] â Count Strimpkin * [[Dustin Diamond]] â Rob * [[Moosie Drier]] â Andy Graves * [[Nancy Dussault]] â Dr. Sandra Brown * [[Nanette Fabray]] â Dottie * [[Norman Fell]] â Mr. Maurice * [[Kathleen Freeman]] â Grandma * [[George Furth]] â Dr. Carver * [[Zsa Zsa Gabor]] â Herself * [[Kip King]] â Burt Fearman * [[Dave Madden]] â Mr. Preston * [[Eddie Mekka]] â Mr. Sweetzer * [[Richard Moll]] â [[Genghis Khan]] * [[Pat Morita]] â Neighbor * [[Don Most]] â Barney Morley * [[Lois Nettleton]] â Jessica Brown * [[Marcia Wallace]] â Dr. Susan Evans * [[Jo De Winter]] â Katja Dracula * Yetta â Shirley {{colend}} ==Production== ===Development=== This color revival of ''[[The Munsters]]'' starred [[John Schuck]] (Herman), [[Lee Meriwether]] (Lily), [[Howard Morton]] (Grandpa), [[Hilary Van Dyke]] (Marilyn) and [[Jason Marsden]] (Eddie), and broadcast 73 episodes from October 8, 1988, to May 25, 1991, giving it more first-run episodes than the original series. The [[Television pilot|pilot]] explained the 22-year gap following the original series by showing the family as they were in 1966 when an accident took place; the family then proceeds to wake up in 1988.{{cite news|title= Munsters Awaken From 22-year Nap|work= Chicago Tribune|date=1988-09-20|url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-09-20/features/8801310728_1_munsters-today-frankenstein-and-dracula-stations-and-cable-companies|accessdate=2010-10-10|first=Kenneth R|last=Clark}} It was created following a failed attempt to revive the show with most of the original cast ([[Fred Gwynne]], [[Al Lewis (actor)|Al Lewis]] and [[Yvonne De Carlo]]) in the 1981 [[NBC]] telefilm ''[[The Munsters' Revenge]]''. In the living room set, there are photos of the original casts sitting on the mantle of the fireplace. ==Episodes== {{div col|colwidth=35em}} ===Season 1 (1988â89)=== * "'''Still the Munsters After All These Years" (Pilot)''' â Grandpa creates a "Sleeping Machine" which makes the user fall asleep for a selected amount of time. While the victim is asleep, his/her age does not change. The machine was tested on the entire family. When Grandpa sets the dial for 30 minutes and shuts the door, a flash of light and a falling beam change the dial to "Forever." Twenty-two years later, a developer named Mr. Preston ([[Dave Madden]]) and his assistant want to buy the Munsters' home and turn it into a [[parking lot]]. Mr. Preston and his assistant are exploring the house. Mr. Preston forces his employee to search Grandpa's lab; after getting tangled in spider webs he knocks the dial to "off." The Munster family awakens to the world of 1988. They all struggle to find their way in the strange new era. * "'''Vampire Pie'''"- Herman decides to enter a baking contest, using an old family recipe. Too bad there was an ingredient Grandpa forgot... * "'''A Little Russian Dressing'''" * "'''Flyweight Champion of the World'''"- After being bullied, Grandpa mixes Eddie a strong-man formula that inflates Eddie's ego as well as his muscles. * "'''Magna Cum Munsters'''"- After feeling useless for not being asked questions in his home, Herman takes night school, which leads him to the fourth grade: in Eddie's class. * "'''Designing Munsters'''" * "'''Farewell, Grandpa'''" â Grandpa is in big trouble when the family finds out he forgot to get a green-card when he came to the country. After Herman breaks him out, only an invisibility potion can save them. * "'''Corporate Munsters'''" â Stock that Herman bought many years ago has accumulated so much that he holds a position in the business. However, he debates keeping the job when it conflicts with Eddie and Father/Son Day. * "'''Herman The Astronaut'''" * "'''Rock Fever'''" * "'''Professor Grandpa'''" * "'''Say Ahh'''" * "'''A Hero Ain't Nothin' but a Cereal'''"- After saving a kid, Herman becomes a hero. When a cereal company offers him a deal, he accepts. But once he finds out the cereal is a flop, will he keep on endorsing it? * "'''Computer Mating'''"- Grandpa gets a new girlfriend after feeling lonely. But after finding out his girlfriend has buried a large amount of husbands, Herman and Lily fear for Grandpa's life. * "'''McMunsters'''" * "'''One Flu Over The Munster's Nest'''" * "'''Green Eyed Munsters'''"- Herman gets jealous when Lily's teacher takes up too much of her time. Will he win her back? * "'''The Not So Great Escape'''" * "'''Two Left Feet'''" * "'''Lights, Camera, Munsters'''" â Marilyn gets to make a movie for a project, while the family debates what type of film she should do. Meanwhile, Eddie is doing poor in school, causing panic for the teacher when it turns out that a parent-teacher conference is in order. * "'''Neighborly Munsters'''" â With new neighbors next door, everyone tries to make a good impression, while the wife tries to do everything to get a fancy pool in her yard (which would dig into the Munster's) except talk with them. * "'''Munster Hoopster'''" â Eddie wants to take up basketball, so that Herman can brag about him. There's only one problem: he cannot sink a shot! * "'''Don't Cry Wolfman'''" â When two burglars hid the fortune in the Munster house, they were asleep. Now that they are awake, they devise a plan: one would pretend to be one of them. Unfortunately, he comes to like the Munster's ways and even saves them. In the end, the "wolfman" burglar and the Munsters all vote to return the money. * "'''The Howling'''" * "'''Eau De Munster'''" When the town wants to demolish Munster Moore for a museum, Herman tries to put a stop to it. There's only one problem: Grandpa accidentally got him with a love potion, which takes effect on the woman running the idea. ===Season 2 (1989â90)=== * "Three Hundred Something" * "No Place Like Home" * "Raging Hormones" * "Murder in Munster Land" * "Trail" * "It's A Wonderful Afterlife" * "The Eyes Have It" * "It's a Sad, Sad World" * "Melting Pot" * "Once in a Blue Moon" * "Drac The Ripper" * "Gateman and Son" * "Reunion" * "Pants on Fire" * "Munstergeist" * "Never Say Die" * "It's a Baby" * "Tell'em Herman Sent You" * "Thicker Than Water" * "Misadventures in Time" * "Will The Real Herman Munster Please Stand Up?" * "Deadlock" * "Take This Job and Shovel It" * "That's Gratitude" ===Season 3 (1990â91)=== * "The Silver Bullet" * "The Reel Munsters" * "Wishing You Were Here" * "Three Munsters and a Baby" * "It's My Party and I'll Die If I Want To" * "Makin' Waves" * "Just Another Pretty Face" (remake of an original episode from [[The Munsters|the 1960s series]]) * "Kiss, Kiss" * "Mind Reader" * "No More Mr. Nice Guy" * "A House Divided" * "A Matter of Trust" * "Large" * "Genie from Hell" * "Lotsa Luck" * "If I Only Knew Now" * "Beating of Your Heart" * "Parenthood vs. Childhood" * "Das Trunk" * "A Camping We Will Go" * "Breaking the Chain" * "Diary of a Mad Munster Wife" * "The Bet" * "Family Night" {{div col end}} ==Reception== The series lasted three seasons on syndicated television, and proved popular with international audiences. ===Awards and nominations=== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 90%;" |- bgcolor="#B0C4DE" align="center" ! Mosko and Carlos Yeaggy |-style="background-color: #EAEAEA;" | rowspan=2|1991 || rowspan=2|'''Won''' || Outstanding Achievement in Makeup || David Abbott, Gilbert A. Mosko and Carlos Yeaggy |-style="background-color: #EAEAEA;" | Outstanding Achievement in Hairstyling || Jody Lawrence |- | rowspan=3|1989 || rowspan=10|[[Young Artist Awards]] || rowspan=3|'''Nominated''' || Best Syndicated Family Drama or Comedy Series ||
â

page.title: The New York Baroque Dance Company

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Pygmalion]] (link changed to [[Pigmalion (opera)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
'''The New York Baroque Dance Company''' is a professional American dance company located in [[New York City]]. It was founded in 1976 (incorporated 1979) by Artistic Director [[Catherine Turocy]] and Ann Jacoby.<ref>Sulcas, Roslyn (September 16, 2007). [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/16/arts/dance/16sulc.html "Baroque Holds Court for a New Age"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116195426/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/16/arts/dance/16sulc.html |date=2018-01-16 }} ''[[The New York Times]].''</ref> With a mission to recreate and preserve the full range of 17th and 18th century dances (operas, court balls, salon performances and street shows) the New York Baroque Dance company also serves the community with educational programs for all levels, from elementary school to university, as well as programs for the general public.
The NYBDC has performed with many leading early music specialists, including [[John Eliot Gardiner]], [[Christopher Hogwood]], [[Nicholas McGegan]] and [[Wolfgang Katschner]] and ensembles that include [[Opera Lafayette|Opera Lafayette Orchestra and Chorus]], The Dallas Bach Society, Mercury Baroque, [[Apollo's Fire]] and [[Philharmonia Baroque]]. In New York City, the company produces annual performances with Concert Royal Orchestra.
Important productions have included [[Jean Philippe Rameau|Jean Philippe Rameau's]] ''[[Les BorÃ©ades]]'' (never performed in the 18th century) and [[Hippolyte et Aricie]] at the [[Aix-en-Provence Festival]] and the [[Opera de Lyon]]; [[Henry Purcell|Henry Purcell's]] ''[[Indian Queen]]'' at London's [[Barbican]]; [[Scylla et Glaucus]] by [[Jean Marie Leclair]] at the Opera de Lyon as well as more than one hundred performances of a double bill of Rameau's ''[[Pigmalion (opera)|Pygmalion]]'' and [[George Frederick Handel|Handel's]] ''[[Terpsicore]]''. At the [[GÃ¶ttingen International Handel Festival|International Handel Festival]] in [[GÃ¶ttingen|GÃ¶ttingen, Germany]] the company has performed many of that composer's works, including ''[[Ariodante]]'', ''[[Arianna in Creta]]'', ''[[Alcina]]'', ''[[Atalanta (opera)|Atalanta]]'', ''[[Orlando (opera)|Orlando]]'', ''Terpsicore'' and ''[[Teseo]]''.
==History== After studying ballet and dance history at [[Ohio State University]] with Shirley Wynne, Turocy and six other dancers formed the Baroque Dance Ensemble which folded in 1975. Turocy relocated to New York City and formed a new company with Ann Jacoby (who had previously danced with the Baroque Dance Ensemble) as The New York Baroque Dance Co. Turocy had met harpsichordist and conductor James Richman at the [[Aston Magna Music Festival]] in 1974, where they were collaborating on music of Rameau, and the two eventually married.<ref>Hughes, Allen (February 9, 1979). [https://www.nytimes.com/1979/02/09/archives/1600s-music-and-dance-join-hands-for-concert-teaching-musicians-to.html "1600's Music and Dance Join Hands for Concert"] ''[[The New York Times]].''</ref> Richman later founded the Concert Royal Orchestra, whose performances date back to their 1977 [[Carnegie Hall]] debut,<ref>Ericson, Raymond (January 8, 1977). [https://www.nytimes.com/1977/01/08/archives/music-authentic-regal-baroque.html "Music: Authentic Regal Baroque"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221050350/http://www.nytimes.com/1977/01/08/archives/music-authentic-regal-baroque.html |date=2018-02-21 }} ''[[The New York Times]].''</ref> and with whom the New York Baroque Dance company has frequently collaborated since their 1977 recreation of dances by [[Jean-Baptiste Lully]], [[Jean-FÃ©ry Rebel]] (''Les Caracteres de la Danse'') and the complete the dance scene from Rameau's pastoral masque, ''[[Les Fetes d'Hebe]]'' at [[Alice Tully Hall]].<ref>Rockwell, John (December 14, 1977). [https://www.nytimes.com/1977/12/14/archives/music-bit-of-baroque.html "Music: Bit of Baroque"] ''[[The New York Times]].''</ref>
In 1997, to celebrate the company's 20th anniversary, [[The New York Public Library]] presented the exhibition: ''The New Baroque: Early Dance Re-creations and Inspirations.'' <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nypl.org/press/1997/baroque.cfm |title=Exhibition explores the history and pageantry of baroque dance and its re-stagings in the 20th century |accessdate=2018-10-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001458/http://www.nypl.org/press/1997/baroque.cfm |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> Ms. Turocy has taught historical performance at the [[Juilliard School]] and (with the New York Baroque Dance Company) has been a guest teacher at the Early Music Institute at [[Indiana University]],<ref name="bar">{{cite web |url=http://info.music.indiana.edu/news/page/normal/3144.html |title=First steps: Baroque dance introduced to a new generation |publisher=[[Indiana University]] |accessdate=2018-10-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150914114835/http://info.music.indiana.edu/news/page/normal/3144.html |archive-date=2015-09-14 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref> [[Oberlin College]], [[Curtis Institute of Music]] and [[Case Western Reserve]]. She directed [[Mozart]]sâs ''[[The Magic Flute]]'' at the [[University of Miami]] in 2013 and is a Chevalier of the [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]].<ref>Gordillo, Bernard (January 14, 2010). [https://indianapublicmedia.org/harmonia/questions-catherine-turocy-baroque-dancer/ "Questions for Catherine Turocy, Baroque Dancer"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002001440/http://indianapublicmedia.org/harmonia/questions-catherine-turocy-baroque-dancer/ |date=2015-10-02 }} ''Indiana Public Media''</ref>
With the New York Baroque Dance Company, Turocy won the 2018 [[Isadora Duncan Dance Awards|Isadora Duncan Dance Award]] for Outstanding Revival at the 32nd annual "Izzie" Awards for the reconstruction of Rameau's 1745 opera-ballet ''[[Le Temple de la Gloire]]'' with the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra & Chorus (sharing the award with Krissy Keefer and Dance Brigade's âThe Great Liberation Upon Hearingâ).<ref>Bauer, Claudia (March 26, 2018). [https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Izzie-awards-span-the-centuries-and-dance-12782177.php#photo-12785056 "Izzie awards span the centuries â and dance today around the Bay Area"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180422024913/https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Izzie-awards-span-the-centuries-and-dance-12782177.php#photo-12785056 |date=2018-04-22 }} ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]].''</ref> This work had previously been presented by NYBDC and Concert Royal at [[Florence Gould Hall]] in 1991.<ref>Oestreich, James R. (September 23, 1991). [https://www.nytimes.com/1991/09/23/arts/review-music-rameau-s-baroque-temple-de-la-gloire.html "Review/Music Rameau's Baroque 'Temple De la Gloire'"] ''[[The New York Times]].''</ref> For her work with the company, Turocy won the 2001 [[Bessie Awards|Bessie Award]] for Sustained Achievement in Choreography.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://bessies.org/archive/ |title=Bessie Award Archive |accessdate=2018-10-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180903171239/http://bessies.org/archive/ |archive-date=2018-09-03 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090808192828/http://www.nybaroquedance.org/home.html New York Baroque Dance Company's homepage] * https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/04/arts/dance/catherine-turocys-lessons-unlock-early-musics-meaning.html
